**Simplified Text:**

Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts that show where you are. The website warned that when you say, "Hey, I’m at this place," you are also telling many people where you are, including some you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing everything online can have negative effects. 

The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a large audience, which can lead to fame or wealth. However, we often share too much and later realize it can be risky. This can feel sad, but we should not lose hope. There are lessons from people who used the internet before us. 

In the early days of the web, a young man named Justin Hall started sharing his life online in 1994. He created a blog where he wrote about everything, and many people read it. Hall was open about his life, but one day, he had to take down his blog because someone he loved did not want him to share their relationship online. He felt that sharing so much made people not trust him. 

In 2002, another woman named Heather Armstrong had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a coworker sent her blog link to the bosses at her company, including some she had made fun of. This caused her to lose her job. 

Experts say this is an example of the "online distribution effect," which means people often say things online that they would never say in person. However, our online lives are connected to our real lives, and if we forget this, we can make big mistakes. 

Heather's story had a happy ending. After taking a break from blogging, she got married and started a new blog about her family. Now, she is successful as a "mommy blogger," and her writing helps support her family. She learned that while the internet lets us say anything, we should think carefully before we share.

Text: 

Some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? This film mixes documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe that we do not understand. How can any scientist argue with that? Scientists can sometimes be a bit arrogant, but even the most confident physicist would not say they know everything about the universe. Still, some scientists felt they needed to warn the public about the film, calling it things like ‘atrocious’ and ‘very dangerous’. This made me curious to see the movie.

At first, I did not understand why there was so much excitement about it. Various scientists made simple statements about how new discoveries were showing that the universe is stranger than we thought. However, when the film talked about some of these discoveries, I began to understand the excitement. One discovery was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher showed that the shape of a water molecule could change based on the thoughts of people around it. But the movie only showed pictures of ice crystals that looked beautiful after being talked to by happy people and ugly after being exposed to angry people. 

Many people find this kind of evidence convincing because it is clear and easy to understand. However, scientists usually respond with skepticism. They want more proof. The idea that water can be affected by thoughts is amazing, but we need solid evidence to believe it. Pretty pictures of crystals are not enough. 

The real issue is that the movie’s claims were not strange enough. For example, water molecules might have properties linked to a mysterious energy that is causing the universe to expand. This idea is supported by decades of research in labs and observatories around the world. 

There are real discoveries that show the universe is stranger than we thought. Astronomers have found that the universe is made of an unknown type of matter and is pushed by a mysterious force called ‘dark energy’. Other discoveries are also surprising. Neuroscientists found that our awareness of events happens about half a second after they actually occur. Anthropologists believe they have found where modern humans first appeared and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even think there are connections between life on Earth and the design of the universe.

Despite what some people might say, science is not finished. In fact, we seem to know less than we thought. Many natural events may never be fully understood. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show that there are limits to what we can know. Some of the best theoretical physicists are trying to create a Theory of Everything, which would explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. 

In the end, many of us believe that the universe can be described in one word: incredible.

Text: "In simple words, I find writing novels hard, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a big forest, while writing a short story is like planting a small garden. Both are important to me and create a beautiful picture. The trees in the forest provide shade, and the wind makes the leaves move, sometimes turning them bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons.

Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have often switched between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after I finish a novel, I want to write short stories. After I complete a group of short stories, I feel ready to focus on a novel again. I never write short stories while I’m writing a novel, and I don’t write a novel when I’m working on short stories. Writing these two types may use different parts of my brain, and it takes time to change from one to the other.

I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I didn’t know much about writing short stories then, so it was difficult, but I found it a memorable experience. I felt my fictional world grow, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first collection called Tales from Abroad. This was how I started as a short-story writer.

One of the best things about writing short stories is that they don’t take long to finish. Usually, it takes me about a week to write a short story (but I can revise it many times). It’s not like the long time and effort needed to write a novel, which can take a year or two. I go into a room, finish my work, and leave. Writing a novel can feel very long, and sometimes I wonder if I will finish it. So, writing short stories gives me a nice change.

Another good thing about short stories is that you can create a story from small ideas – a thought, a word, or an image. It’s often like jazz music, where the story goes where it wants. Also, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn’t work out, you can just accept it and move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t write a perfect story every time. This makes me feel better. You can learn from your mistakes and use that knowledge in your next story.

When I write novels, I try to learn from what works and what doesn’t in my short stories. In this way, short stories are like a practice space for me as a novelist. It is hard to try new things in a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even harder for me. My short stories are like soft shadows I have left in the world, and I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt. Short stories are like signs to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers."

**Simplified Text:**

Science is a way of understanding the world. It can help us cure diseases and make our lives easier, but it can also create problems. Science tries to explain everything from tiny atoms to the vast universe. It has influenced many areas of life, including art and politics. Sometimes, people do not understand how important science is, and they may either overestimate or underestimate its value. Scientists often disagree with each other, and new ideas can change what we believe. 

This book will focus on important scientific ideas that have changed how we think. While science has practical uses, we will mainly look at its ideas and their beauty. We will also remember that science can be limited and that scientists can make mistakes. Science is always changing. There is always a scientist who is proving another scientist wrong. Most of the time, these changes do not affect society much. However, sometimes, new ideas can change our beliefs completely.

For example, in the 1600s, scientists thought the universe worked like a giant clock. But later, new discoveries changed this view. Some people think that the changing nature of science means it cannot explain the universe well. However, when science changes, it often helps us understand and predict nature better. For instance, Isaac Newton explained more about the universe than the ancient Greek thinker Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained even more than Newton.

Science has made many discoveries in the last two centuries, such as radioactivity, X-rays, and the electron. Today, some people believe we are close to finding a complete theory that explains everything about the universe. Science is not just a fun activity; it has real effects on our lives. We have moved from just observing nature to controlling it in some ways. This can sometimes upset the balance of nature, and we need to be careful.

Everyone should understand science because it affects our future and the world our children will live in. The decisions made in science can impact health, the economy, and even the future of life on Earth.

Text: 

Since around 2015, many big publishers have noticed that ebook sales have stopped growing and, in some cases, have even gone down. This has raised questions about the future of ebooks in the publishing world. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks may have led to bad investments, making his company lose faith in the value of printed books. Even though it seems clear that ebooks and print books can exist together, people still wonder if ebooks will replace print books. This idea is interesting and causes a lot of discussions. 

Why do we think of ebooks and print books as being in competition? The answers to these questions go beyond just ebooks and show how we feel about change and new technology. In my research, I found that people often worry that new technologies will replace older ones. For example, when television was invented, many people thought radio would disappear. But radio found new ways to be used, like listening in cars or at work. 

The idea that books might disappear is not new. In 1894, some people thought that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times with movies, radio, and smartphones, which have all been said to threaten print books. Some people believe that if books disappear, it will be bad for culture. Others think that ebooks will bring great benefits. 

The idea of books disappearing often comes up when new technology is introduced. This idea shows our mixed feelings about change. We form strong emotional connections with different media, like books and computers. Studies show that we can even name our cars or get upset when our laptops don’t work. So, when new technology, like e-readers, appears, it changes our relationship with things we have always used. 

As technology changes, we often miss what we used to have. This is why some people still enjoy older products. For example, when the printing press was invented in the 15th century, people wanted original manuscripts. When movies changed from silent to sound in the 1920s, people felt nostalgic for silent films. The same thing happened when photography changed from analog to digital and when vinyl records changed to CDs. 

E-readers have made many people appreciate the physical qualities of printed books, even their smell. This should make those who worry about print books feel a bit better. However, the idea that books might disappear will continue to be a popular story about how technology changes our lives and how we feel about that change. We often use familiar stories, like those about tragedy and endings, to understand change. The story of the death of the book reflects both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing things that are important to us.

Text: 

For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday morning. I brushed my teeth, made a cup of coffee, and wrote about how some of the greatest thinkers of the last four hundred years managed their time. I wanted to understand how they organized their days to be creative and productive. By writing about the everyday details of their lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I hoped to show a different side of their personalities and careers. 

The French writer Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, “Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.” I believe, “Tell me what time you eat, and whether you take a nap afterward.” This book is not just about the final work of these people; it is about their daily routines. I also share my own struggles: How can you do meaningful creative work while making a living? Is it better to focus on one project or to work a little each day? When there is not enough time, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house, or can you learn to do more in less time?

I do not have all the answers, but I have tried to show how many successful people faced similar challenges. I wanted to explain how big creative ideas can be broken down into small daily tasks and how our habits can affect our work. The title of the book is Daily Rituals, but it is really about people’s routines. A routine can seem boring, but it can also help us use our time, energy, and optimism better. 

The psychologist William James believed that having good habits can help us focus on more interesting things. Ironically, he was often a procrastinator and struggled to keep a regular schedule. My own idea for this book came from a moment of procrastination. One Sunday afternoon, I was at my job at a small architecture magazine, trying to write a story that was due the next day. Instead of working, I was cleaning my desk and making coffee. I am a “morning person,” so I decided to look online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought it would be great to collect them. This led to the Daily Routines blog I started that day and now this book.

The blog was simple; I shared descriptions of people’s routines from biographies and articles. For the book, I have gathered more detailed and researched information while keeping the variety of voices that made the blog interesting. I have let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from their letters, diaries, and interviews. In some cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. I want to thank the many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work helped me. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section for those who want to read more.

**Simplified Text:**

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, said that their planned holiday to Spain was not possible anymore. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. One rainy August afternoon, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. He had wanted to be a palaeontologist for a long time. By the end of his time at university, he knew what kind of palaeontologist he wanted to be. He was not interested in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. Instead, he was fascinated by the very beginning of life on Earth and studied small creatures found in grey rocks.

When he finished his doctoral thesis, he wondered if he would get a job. He felt confident about his abilities, but he knew that sometimes, good people do not get the jobs they deserve. When a job opened at Tavistock College in London, he applied right away, but he did not have high hopes.

On the day of Howard’s interview, the professor who was supposed to lead the panel had a fight with his wife. He left home upset, crashed his car, and went to the hospital. The interview happened without him. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, took his place on the panel. This professor helped Howard get the job, even though Howard did not know him. At first, Howard was very grateful, but later a colleague explained that it was not because of his skills. Howard felt a little disappointed but was mostly happy to have the job and do the work he loved.

Howard often thought about how organized his work life was, where he could plan and follow through on his research. In contrast, his personal life was chaotic. Sometimes, unexpected things could change everything. For example, his briefcase with his lecture notes was stolen at a train station. Angry, Howard went back to the college, called to explain, and postponed his lecture. He reported the theft and then went for a coffee. There, he met a colleague who was with a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. Howard learned about a new collection of fossils that needed to be studied. This could be a great opportunity for him. Because of the theft, he changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students on a trip to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Text: 

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University in the UK, and he is very open to trying new foods. He even has ice cream made from bee larvae at home! Although they look like maggots, they taste a bit nutty and floral. Spence and his team are working on how to make eating bugs more acceptable. He studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we taste. This research affects what we eat and drink, from big food companies to popular restaurants.

Spence's book, The Perfect Meal, co-written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, shares interesting facts about food. For example, did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their meal more? Also, we eat about 35% more food when we are with one other person, and 75% more when we are with three people.

Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and not very modern. He has soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work with chefs who cannot pay for research. Much of his work is supported by a large food company. In the past, some people thought that research funded by companies was not real science. However, now it is important for universities to show that their work matters to people.

Spence helps food brands reduce salt and sugar in their products. It is important for these companies to keep their customers healthy. Many brands make these changes slowly so that customers do not notice the difference. Spence explains that when people know about the changes, they focus on the taste and often do not like it as much.

Spence met famous chef Heston Blumenthal while working on a project for a food company. At first, people thought mixing science and food was strange, but Spence and Blumenthal worked together to create a dish called "Sound of the Sea." Spence has found that music can change how we taste food. For example, high-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while low-pitched sounds can make it taste bitter. Soon, an airline will match music with the food they serve to passengers.

Spence's dinner parties are unique. One time, they ate rabbit with the fur around the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled light bulbs. They have even had dinner parties with headphones and different drinks to see how sound affects taste. For Spence, home, sweet shops, food events, and conferences are all part of his research.

**Simplified Text:**

Our brains are working harder than ever. We are bombarded with facts, false information, and rumors that we need to sort through to find what is important. At the same time, we are doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents helped us book flights and salespeople helped us find items in stores. Now, we do most of these tasks on our own. We are trying to manage many responsibilities, like our jobs, families, hobbies, and favorite TV shows, often with the help of our smartphones. These devices help us fill every free moment with activities.

However, there is a problem. We think we are multitasking, or doing many things at once, but this is a dangerous illusion. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks. Each time we switch, it costs us mental energy. Instead of being like expert jugglers, we are more like amateur plate spinners, quickly moving from one task to another and worrying about what we might drop.

Even though we believe we are getting a lot done, multitasking makes us less efficient. It can increase stress hormones in our bodies, which can make us feel confused or foggy. Multitasking can also create a craving for constant stimulation, making it hard to focus. The part of our brain that helps us stay focused can easily be distracted by new things, like shiny objects that catch our attention.

Just having the chance to multitask can hurt our ability to think clearly. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, found that trying to focus on a task while seeing an unread email can lower our IQ by almost 10 points. He showed that the mental losses from multitasking are worse than those from being tired. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, found that learning new information while multitasking can send that information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, the information may not be stored properly, making it harder to remember later.

Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to answer a text message or ignore it. Making decisions is hard for our brains, and small decisions can use as much mental energy as big ones. After making many small decisions, we can end up making poor choices about important matters.

In discussions about information overload, email is often mentioned as a problem. It is not that email itself is bad, but the huge amount of messages we receive can be overwhelming. When a 10-year-old boy was asked what his father does, he said, "He answers emails." His father agreed that this was quite true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it often feels impossible to do that and complete other tasks.

**Simplified Text:**

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right way to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people thought these questions were not important. Animals had behaviors, and science only looked at the results of those behaviors. The idea that animals have feelings and thoughts was seen as silly. But this has started to change. Research on bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to show that animals have emotions. This new understanding has appeared in popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s *Wild Justice* and Victoria Braithwaite’s *Do Fish Feel Pain?* This has started a debate that may never be fully answered: do animals have consciousness? This debate leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong that guides their behavior? 

In a recent experiment with cows, researchers found that cows that opened a locked gate to get food were happier than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for how we raise and eat beef? While the observations are clear, people disagree on what they mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote *Second Nature*, believes we should stop eating meat. He thinks we are close to a big change in how we think about ethics, similar to when slavery was abolished. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, believes we should rethink how we understand animal thinking. He says animals likely have a simpler way of thinking than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop thinking of animals as if they are just like us. 

These three views may never agree because the main issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. It is very hard to define consciousness. Can we ever really know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe describes an important experiment he did that suggests starlings, a type of bird, can feel depressed. In a study at Newcastle University, starlings were divided into two groups. One group lived in nice cages with plenty of space and water, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. But when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the starlings in the nice cages would eat. Balcombe concluded that living in a bad cage made the starlings feel negative about life. 

Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a strong opinion. He says, “We look back with disgust at a time when there was racism. One day, we will feel the same about how we view animals. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.” If he were the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning shares similar ideas. Manning has written a textbook called *An Introduction to Animal Behaviour*. He says, “What we are seeing is a swing in ideas. In the early 20th century, some people thought animals thought just like us, and then there was a reaction against that. Now we are moving back to the idea that animals have thoughts and feelings. But this is a complicated topic, and we should be careful about listening to academics with strong personal opinions.”

**Simplified Text:**

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear more deeply. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation in the U.K., believes that arguing can help us find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there are worries that it also changes how we solve complex problems and makes it harder to think clearly. West says we are often exposed to poor thinking and popular opinions that can confuse us. Even though we have more information than ever, it does not always lead to better knowledge or decisions. 

According to the National Endowment for the Arts, fewer people are reading books, and this decline is getting faster. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, thinks that focusing more on visual media, like videos and games, may hurt our critical thinking skills. She says people are multitasking and not concentrating on one thing. However, we still do not have a clear answer about how technology affects critical thinking. 

Technology has changed how we think, and it can have both positive and negative effects. For example, some computer games can help improve critical thinking, while browsing the internet can distract us from deeper thinking. Greenfield has studied how visual media affect learning. She explains that reading helps us think and use our imagination better than visual media like video games and TV. Reading develops our imagination, reflection, and vocabulary. However, she also found that some visual media can help with processing information. Unfortunately, many visual media do not give us time to think or reflect.

This situation means that many young people may not reach their full potential. How society views technology affects how we think about critical thinking. There is a debate about video games and their impact on learning. James Paul Gee, a professor of educational psychology, says that video games can be good for kids. They are not just entertainment; they can also be useful for learning. Research shows that playing games can help children develop better reasoning skills. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in fun, virtual environments that are similar to the real world. These games allow players to explore ideas that they might not be able to in real life. 

In today’s digital age, as reading and math scores go down, we need to look more closely at technology and understand how it affects our thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not thinking and writing about how we should live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after he became unhappy with working in an office and for social policy organizations. His first book was about the good things about manual work. His latest book talks about how to deal with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he was shopping and saw advertisements on the credit card machine while he was entering his pin number. Crawford realized that it is becoming harder to avoid these distractions. What we want to think about at any moment is personal, but we often cannot choose this for ourselves because of things we do not notice. It is getting more difficult to think or remember conversations we have had. Because everyone wants to avoid being interrupted, we often stop talking to strangers. Crawford says, “We see the world through things that are made for us, like video games and apps on our phones.” These things reflect our desires and can take over our lives. 

Crawford is not the only one who is worried. Many office workers complain about emails all day and then spend their free time checking emails. Studies show that our attention can wander if a phone is just sitting on the table. Many of us have felt bored at dinner, wanting to check our phones. There is no scientific proof yet that our attention spans have changed, but people have worried about this since the telegraph was invented in 1837. It is clear that we are more aware of other things we could be doing. Some people think this problem is caused by technology, but Crawford believes that technology has made it easier for us to focus on ourselves. 

Having many choices makes it hard for us to control ourselves, and this affects our social lives. We often prefer to send a text message to a friend instead of talking to them. Crawford argues that by only interacting with representations of people, like through screens, we might lose something important in our society. He uses his gym as an example. There used to be one music player in the middle of the room for everyone to use. People had different music tastes, which could cause some tension. Now, people listen to their own music with earbuds. “The gym used to be a social place, but it has lost that feeling,” he says. Real connections with others often happen when there is some conflict, like discussing different music tastes.

Crawford has two suggestions to help with this problem. First, we need to control noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he believes we should practice skills that help us engage with the world in a more satisfying way. He gives examples of a cook, an ice hockey player, and a motorcycle racer. These people must deal with real things in their work. No video game can replace the feeling of a hockey puck on ice or gravel under your tires when you ride fast. Each of these roles requires good judgment and the ability to work with others in the same space. “When you engage with the world this way, fake experiences show themselves as weak compared to real experiences,” he says. “They lose some of their power.” 

This does not mean everyone should become a chef, but it is important to find ways to use your judgment. There are many benefits beyond job satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions can be tiring and makes it harder to focus on what is important. On the other hand, paying attention to one thing makes it easier to pay attention to other things.

Text: 

"What do you do for a living?" This is a common question in small talk, and we often define ourselves by our jobs. However, if you are a philosopher like me, it can be a bit tricky to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit showy. It is better to say you study or teach philosophy. Many people think that being a philosopher means you know some special truth, but that is not true. Philosophers are just like everyone else.

One reason people think this way is that philosophers often judge what others do and celebrate thinking. The Greek philosopher Aristotle believed that a life of thinking was the best kind of life. While not all modern philosophers agree, philosophy is still seen as connected to deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said that "the unexamined life is not worth living." This means that just going along with what everyone else thinks is not very satisfying. Our ability to think about the world helps us control our lives and make our own choices.

However, living an examined life does not mean you have to read many difficult philosophical books or spend all your time thinking. It just means paying more attention to the everyday experiences that shape our lives. You do not have to be a wise person living away from society to do this. In fact, examining our lives can be very practical and should be shared with others because it is important for a good life.

Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become more separate from real life, especially for those who do not have formal training. This is not only the philosophers' fault; universities often focus on expensive academic journals, making it hard for philosophers to share their ideas with anyone outside their small group of experts. Because of this, philosophy can seem very distant from everyday life. While some philosophers used to challenge this view, many have accepted it. The academic world has created a situation where philosophers are often isolated from society.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I work in ethics, which is the part of philosophy that looks at human actions. Recently, I have felt that this title does not fully describe my work because ethics is often linked to formal rules and laws. There is a new way of thinking in ethics that looks at whether certain social practices are fair or just. The job of an ethicist today is to decide if something is "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions that I think about often.

A typical discussion might start by asking if downloading movies illegally is wrong (it is) and then move on to questions about responsibility, our views on art, and how consumerism affects us. Philosophy can help people think more deeply about the actions and behaviors that shape their lives. Sometimes we might find out something we already knew; other times, we may realize that our beliefs are hard to defend. By examining these ideas, we can do something good for everyone.

**Simplified Text:**

People who love food, like foodies and chefs, might think that thinking about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in history, discussions about food have often been less important than other philosophical topics. When philosophers talk about eating, they usually use it as a way to discuss something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, conversations about food seem to be about food, but they often explore deeper ideas that are not directly related.

One interesting philosopher is Epicurus, who believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in many areas of life. His name is now often connected with enjoying food and drink. You can see his name in restaurants and food shops because these businesses hope to attract customers by linking their products to a famous philosopher.

Food is also social and cultural. The food we eat comes from history and is shared with people in our communities. These communities help us grow and share food. We interact with food more than with any other product, making it a good topic for philosophical discussion. After food is prepared, critics start to talk and write about it. But why do these critics have such a special role? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a special skill; rather, good food critics are just better at describing what food tastes like. This area of taste has not been studied much, as most research has focused on how we see things.

Another important part of food is its beauty. We often talk about paintings or music being beautiful, but we don’t usually talk about the taste of food in the same way. Some philosophers believe that, because of modern cooking, food deserves to be discussed as art, like sculpture or poetry. However, food is eaten and gone after we enjoy it, unlike art that can last over time. So, it is not correct to think of food as a true art form.

There are also many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our answers often show our beliefs about what is right or wrong. Philosophers will always question why we choose what we do, and discussing these ideas about food is important.

Cooking at home and in restaurants can be very different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of their personal relationships. In a home kitchen, everyone shares food and time together. But professional cooks have responsibilities to their employers and the food itself. Their kitchens are not open to everyone, and their relationships are more like colleagues than friends.

A recent essay called "Diplomacy of the Dish" looks at how food and eating can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: first, we can learn to appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food; second, we can build friendships with people from other cultures by sharing meals. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories that make this part of food philosophy come alive for readers.

Rob Daviau is from the US and he designs special board games called ‘legacy’ games. He felt that the traditional board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. This made him think about how board games could change. He wondered if they could have a story and if choices made in one game could affect the next game. 

He took a classic board game called Risk and made a new version called Risk Legacy. In this game, decisions made by players during the game have lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, change the board, or open new packets with different rules at important moments. The games are played over several sessions, and players can hold grudges against each other. Daviau said, “You could point to the board and say: ‘Right here! You did this!’”

Later, he worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to cure diseases. His next game was called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very successful, SeaFall was seen as a big test for the legacy format because it was the first game that did not come from an earlier version. In SeaFall, players become sailors in the 16th to 19th century and explore a new world.

Designers of legacy games must think about all the choices players can make to keep the story interesting. They use play-testers to see how the games work. Jaime Barriga was a play-tester for SeaFall. He said, “It takes a lot of time. At first, the game is great, but after a few games, it can start to break. Then you have to go back and fix everything.”

Legacy games were not expected to be very popular. Daviau thought it would only be interesting to a small group of people. He said, “I thought I would be known as the guy who did this strange project.” However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He believes it is one of the best improvements in game design in years. He said, “It’s a new level of commitment and excitement.”

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said that the fun of a new adventure was more important than worrying about how long the game would last. He mentioned that people don’t usually watch the same movie twice in the cinema. “You’re buying into an experience,” he said. The legacy format is inspired by video games and popular TV shows. 

While in college, Daviau wanted to be a television writer but later moved into advertising and game design. He still loves telling stories. Matt Leacock, the creator of Pandemic, compared making legacy games to writing a novel. He said, “You need to know how you want it to end and where you want it to begin, but you also need more than just a basic plan.”

Daviau feels proud of his work but is curious to see how others will use the idea. He thinks that soon gamers will want something new. Colby Dauch, the studio manager for SeaFall’s publisher, believes the legacy format has changed how people think about board games.

Not long ago, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He crawled across the floor and squeezed into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was exciting and was shared a lot online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think that animals are similar to us. Octopuses are especially interesting because they are very smart and look very different from humans. 

Octopuses can do amazing things like open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells for protection, and even play games. Some scientists believe that we often ignore the smart traits of animals. Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, says that we should recognize these traits instead of denying them. He has studied animal intelligence for many years and found that animals can think about the past and future, show empathy, and understand what others want. This means animals are smarter than we usually think.

In the past, people believed that animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even Charles Darwin, who changed how we see our place in the world, said that the difference between human and animal minds is just a matter of degree, not kind. However, in the twentieth century, many people started to see animals as simple machines that only respond to rewards and punishments. This view became popular at the same time that humans were harming animal habitats and not caring for animals properly.

Now, Dr. de Waal believes we are starting to understand animal intelligence better. He says that we are learning that animal thinking is similar to human thinking, even if it is not the same. He mentions that the best tests for animal intelligence should consider what each species is good at. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hide their nuts.

In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might judge us by how well we can change the colors of our skin. If we fail, the octopus might think we are not very smart. 

Dr. de Waal is not completely sure that Inky really found his way to the ocean. He knows that other octopuses have escaped before, but it might be too hopeful to think Inky knew how to do it. He also understands that stories like Inky’s help people appreciate animal intelligence. 

He once did an experiment with capuchin monkeys to see if they could feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers (which they like) and others got grapes (which they like even more), the monkeys with cucumbers got very upset. This study was published in a scientific journal, but what really made people believe it was a short video of the experiment released later. This shows how our minds work in interesting ways.

Text: 

Robotics, once just a part of science fiction, is now changing our world in a big way. Robots have been used in car and factory work for many years, but experts say we are about to see robots used in many more areas. Many people think that robots will take over most jobs done by humans in the next 50 years. However, about 80% of people believe their own jobs will still exist in the same way during that time. This shows that people feel their jobs are safe, but they might not be. Every job sector will be affected by robots in the coming years.

For example, an Australian company called Fastbrick Robotics has created a robot named Hadrian X. This robot can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a job that would take two human workers a whole day or more. Another example is a robot called Tally, made by a startup in San Francisco. Tally moves around supermarkets to check that products are in the right place and priced correctly, rather than cleaning the aisles.

Supporters of robots say that robots cannot fix or program themselves yet. This means new jobs will be created for skilled workers like technicians and programmers. However, some people worry that we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. They believe society is not ready for the changes that will come when human interaction is less valued.

Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing jobs. His recent report says that in two years, about one-third of robots will be smarter and able to work with other robots and humans safely. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will create laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will rise by at least 60%, but many jobs will still be open because there are not enough skilled workers.

Zhang believes that automation will affect lower-skilled workers, which is unfortunate. He thinks these workers should not wait for the government to protect their jobs but should find ways to learn new skills. People cannot expect to do the same job for their whole lives anymore.

New technologies will also create a new type of robots for consumers, like robots that can walk and live in our homes and interact with us in smart ways. This is a big chance for companies that can take advantage of these changes. However, it also brings challenges, like the need for new rules to keep us safe and protect our privacy. With many jobs at risk and a global employment crisis coming, it is important to focus on education to prepare for the future workforce with robots. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) to stay competitive.

Text: George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, is known for saying he wanted to climb Mount Everest "because it’s there." This answer shows a common question people have: why do climbers take such big risks? Some people might feel inspired by his answer to follow their own dreams. Climbing can be about adventure and fun, not just reaching the top of a mountain.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He described seven different types of climbing activities, from playing on small rocks to climbing high mountains. Each type has its own rules, and the way climbers choose to climb depends on these rules. This idea has become popular in climbing discussions in the West, appearing in magazines and conversations.

Many climbers love the feeling of freedom that climbing gives them. However, climbing can also feel very limiting. For example, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not what most people think of as freedom. This creates a contradiction in climbing. But some argue that having fewer choices can actually make life simpler and give a different kind of freedom.

US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is part of our nature. It is in our genes to take on challenges, even if they are risky. The joy we find in climbing is more about our biology than just thinking logically.

Another important idea comes from US academic Brian Treanor. He says that climbing can help us develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. While not all climbers show these qualities, Treanor believes they are especially important in today’s world.

Some climbers think that those who climb without help from others or technology must be very dedicated to succeed. Experts Ebert and Robinson stirred some debate by saying that climbing alone is harder and deserves more recognition than climbing with a team or using tools like bottled oxygen. However, this idea might encourage some climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Climbing can also be understood outside of Western ideas. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "going with the flow." The physical effort, the focus needed while climbing, and the problem-solving involved are all key parts of the experience. Some believe that climbing is similar to Zen philosophy, which teaches how to calm the mind and find peace. This idea adds another layer to understanding why people are drawn to climbing.

Text: 

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel was very important in classical music. He was a serious person who studied and recorded many famous European piano works. He wrote and performed a lot, but he did not teach many students. People who knew him saw a fun side to him, but he rarely showed it during his concerts. His life was a busy mix of studying, traveling, and performing.

About four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked him for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take this request seriously. He had very few students and did not see a reason to start teaching now. He remembered a famous pianist who said, “You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.” However, Brendel was impressed by Kit, who was about 14 years old. He listened to Kit play and said, “He played very well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a recital he had done, and it was so beautiful that I thought, ‘I have to make time for him.’ It is rare to find a musician who understands music so well.”

As Brendel steps back from performing, Kit is starting to become more known. Kit, now 19, is always busy learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all while his mother watches over him. He also composes music. Brendel says, “This is very important. Learning to read music is easier when you try to write your own. I noticed that Kit has an amazing memory and can read music very well. He listens to his own playing and understands what I explain to him. When I tell him something to do in one part of a piece, he can do it in other parts too.”

Brendel is careful not to raise expectations for Kit. He gets upset when newspapers call Kit the great pianist of the 21st century. He thinks this is harmful. He knows that gifted young musicians can play some things very well, but they still need time and experience to improve in other areas. It can be harmful if a critic expects too much.

Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed in his life after performing. He says, “When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by the time I was 50. When I turned 50, I felt I had done most of those things, but I still wanted to do more, so I continued. Even though I don’t have the same physical strength now, I still have many ideas in my mind and pieces I have never played. I don’t perform now, but I enjoy this new phase of my career.”

Text: 

When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My Grandad’s garden was by a river and sloped down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – peaceful and quiet. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a fancy greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass.

At home, my father was often quiet. He had a sense of humor and liked to say funny phrases, like “It’s immaterial to me.” He didn’t finish school and became a plumber, which he didn’t love. He wasn’t very ambitious, although he once thought about moving to Canada with my mother, but it didn’t happen. He was good at fixing things around the house, like bookshelves and cupboards. My parents only moved house once, but my mother loved changing the furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, she would bring in another. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it made me nervous. I liked the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy, and they disappeared while I was at school. I never got to play the piano; my sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I couldn’t play, she said, “You’d never have practiced.”

Of the places to explore – moors, woods, or the river – I always chose the river. I could imagine a different world there. With a fishing net and old sandals, I would walk along the riverbank, looking for a good spot to take off my sandals and have a picnic. I would try to catch fish, but after failing to keep them alive in the yard, I would return them to the water.

I wanted to leave school quickly, but it seemed impossible until one day my father said, “There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might like it.” In that moment, he surprised me. He might have preferred if I became a carpenter, but I like to think he saw my interest in gardening. Even though he didn’t like gardening himself, I believe he noticed my passion for plants and flowers.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I am with him. A strong wind is blowing, and it feels like we might be blown off the cliff and into the ocean below. But Lawrence’s sheepdog, Tie, comes close, and Lawrence gently pets him. Even with the strong wind, Lawrence feels comfortable on his island. 

Lawrence shows me around his neighborhood. He points to the north and shouts, “That island is Eigg. The one next to it is the Isle of Rum. It gets more rain than we do.” I see dark clouds pouring rain on Rum’s big mountains. “Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.” 

Suddenly, Lawrence says, “I have sheep to move.” We start walking down the hill. He tells me about the island: Muck is three kilometers long and one and a half kilometers wide; the geese here eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. 

While herding the sheep, Tie is not doing a good job. “Away to me, Tie. Away to me,” Lawrence says, meaning the dog should go to the right. But Tie goes straight through the flock, causing confusion. Lawrence sounds disappointed. “That will never do.” Tie looks ashamed.

The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son Colin manages the island cottages, and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. “They go out the door and come back only when they are hungry.”

But living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is not always available. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I see Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I also have no mobile phone service. “You can get a signal on the hill,” Mary tells me. “Most people last a couple of days without their phones and then put them away.” So I do the same.

Life on Muck is surprising. A boat arrives today with groceries and three musicians who come to play music. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is very popular, and the islanders enjoy the music. 

That night, while sitting by a warm fire and listening to the rain outside, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. “Her father saw a small farm on the Isle of Soay in a newspaper and bought it without looking at it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.” Did Jenny know how to run a farm? “She had good typing skills.”

I go to bed with the sound of rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, as most of the food comes from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I carry it back through the village and give it to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious.

The next morning, I worry about my ferry ride to the next island. Many ferries had been canceled in the last two months because of rough seas. If my ferry does not come, I will be stuck on Muck for two more days. But secretly, I wish for that to happen, phone or no phone.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and self-taught people. Many people thought of video games as just a hobby for young fans, but now the industry is taken seriously. This change may surprise some, but experts in the field are not surprised. However, getting into the video game industry is not easy. Making video games based on new movies needs many team members and a lot of skill and hard work.

Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says, "It is very hard to make progress in big companies or to change the big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. They need not just the top people who manage the whole game, but also the lower-level people who design parts of the game."

So, how can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a degree in computer science, but Jim thinks differently. He says, "The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something. Game design is more than a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, you must do it to understand it."

Another expert, John Field, agrees but adds that it is more complicated. "Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs today. Even fewer have the creativity, technical skills, and vision to help the industry grow."

Can you succeed on your own? John says, "Maybe, but it is difficult. A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and have a strong interest in arts and culture. They may have worked for a few years after graduation but know that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand how diverse the industry is. 

Connections can also help. This is often forgotten, but to succeed in games, like in many other fields, you need to network."

The old idea of a young boy playing video games all day has changed. Now, video games attract many adults and families. Smartphones have introduced many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. "Games are now popular with many different audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this area growing with many new possibilities and opportunities."

Text: "Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me. I am thankful for that. I had a friend whose dad was very strict. He always said, ‘You can’t do this, you can’t do that.’ My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and has not played football since. I am glad that did not happen to me, but I know things could have been different.

When I score a great goal from far away, people often say it is just luck, but it is not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was a kid. You can only score amazing goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes I see young players bumping into each other, but I learned the right techniques. When I teach kids, I always tell them to enjoy learning new skills.

At school, I played many sports, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but football was my main focus back then. The teachers were doing a good job, but I did not notice it at the time. I do not want my son to be like that. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope he does not just want to kick the books around like I did.

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players like us could play for the first team. He never made a big deal about it, but we all knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A famous TV presenter said, ‘You can’t win anything with kids.’ This made us realize how much we needed to improve. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team.

I depend a lot on my close friends and family. Having money can sometimes cause problems. For example, people ask me why I let my mother keep working. I have helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would not like to feel like they need my money. My mum does not earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I enjoy using my money to help the people around me.

I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. Having money does not solve all my problems. After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off or even longer to do things I have not been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I cannot do that now because if I break a leg while skiing and cannot play football again, I would not be insured."

Text: 

We lived at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to help us find a cheap place to live because my father was having a hard time writing there. He could not write anything good, and Sam was worried about losing his clients and money.

During the summer, the beach was quiet because the sun was often covered by sea fog. Few people visited Reef Point. The road to get there was not nice, and a better resort called La Carmella was nearby. Most people chose to stay there instead. Only those who had no money or loved surfing would come to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people were at the beach. After being alone for months, we were now surrounded by people and activities.

My father was busy every day trying to write a script. He was stressed and not in a good mood. While he worked, I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty started to follow me. I tried to send him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but he didn’t really want to hurt him. Rusty knew this and came closer. I asked my father, “Who does he belong to? He thinks he belongs to us.” My father replied, “You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.”

Rusty loved the beach. He liked to dig and bring things to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel. I had to return those to their owners. Rusty also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim faster. He never got tired of it.

That day, we had been swimming. My father had finished his script and went to Los Angeles to deliver it. Rusty and I spent the afternoon playing in the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we sat watching the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. One surfer caught my attention. She was very good and made the others look clumsy. When she decided to stop, she rode in on a final wave.

“Hi,” she said. “Why didn’t you join us?” 

“I don’t have a surfboard.”

“You could get one.”

“I have no money.”

“You’re British, right? Are you visiting?”

“No, I live here.”

“Is your father American?”

“No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.”

“Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?”

“Rufus Marsh.”

“You mean, Tall as the Morning?” 

I nodded. “I read that book from start to finish.” 

She looked at me with new interest. I thought this was how it always was. People were friendly but only showed interest when I mentioned Tall as the Morning.

Text: 

"What have I done?" Violet Hetherington asked herself. She was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton. The line was outside the building marked ‘Departures’ where people were waiting to board the Queen Caroline. No one was moving. Her friend Annie had told her, "It’s best to get to the docks late. If you arrive too early, you will just wait around." Annie, who was married to a diplomat and traveled a lot, usually gave good advice. But this time, she was wrong.

After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a problem with the computer system. The mood among the waiting passengers became worse. Some tried to be patient, and a few even tried to be cheerful, but most people were unhappy. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and they wanted to enjoy it. Violet felt like leaving. She reached into her bag for her phone but realized it was missing. This was more annoying than the long wait. It made her feel that going on a cruise was a mistake. 

Now, she had the problem of her phone. She couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she left it in the taxi because all her important numbers were in her phone. This was the mistake her older son Harry always warned her about. Behind her in the line, there was a friendly couple. "I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a call?" Violet asked. She called Harry using the couple’s phone and left a message for him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if the phone was in her flat. If it wasn’t there, she would be in trouble because she had no other way to find the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her thought, "Thank goodness," but she didn’t tell Harry this. Harry thought he was more experienced than his mother. Daniel, her younger son, was more understanding of her mistakes, but he might forget to give the message to Kristina.

Finally, the line started to move, and Violet went to a window where she gave her travel documents and got ready to board. Her heart sank when she entered the ship’s lobby, which looked like a cheap hotel trying to be fancy. There were shiny fake wood panels, big chandeliers, shiny brass, and carpets like those in airports. Violet followed the signs to the ‘Elevators,’ which were full of mirrors and crowded with tired passengers. They all looked worn out from their early morning travels. Violet was pressed against the side of the lift as it went up, stopping at each floor to let people out. Finally, on the twelfth floor, she stepped out and felt free. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had asked for. She had been worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a better deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to make sure she had a nice view of the sea.

Text: 

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was starting to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures to use in a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer who had a talent for capturing interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has collected many items related to Maier’s life and work. In his home, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes.

One morning, Maloof looked around at all the items he had. He felt he was close to discovering something special, and it happened by chance. “When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,” Maloof said. “I could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They spoke with families who had hired her as a nanny and talked to people at the shop where she developed her film.

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and had a unique style. She often wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, she would have her camera around her neck and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.”

Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. Even though she was not very social, she liked to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist and followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “She didn’t let anything stop her.”

Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for money. Her photos often show women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. “What is interesting about Vivian is that she has many fascinating pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style. “Was Vivian very skilled, or did she take ideas from those before her?” Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. 

Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I improved as a photographer and looked back at her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized I had something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known and to get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

Text: 

When people say a novel is ambitious, they often mean it might not succeed. But this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, but she seemed calm, especially for someone in her twenties. She had just arrived from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. 

Eleanor shared a story about being stopped at passport control. An official asked her to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s. A series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men is trying to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past gave her characters many chances for complications and misunderstandings. The book is more than 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a good chance to shine. 

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she said it feels nice to come from a small country. She feels that everyone at home shares in her success. She mentioned getting a lot of support from people’s grandmas. However, she finds it annoying when people think her book is not serious or philosophical. 

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, where each part is half the length of the part before it. The story speeds up as it goes along. I asked if it matters if readers notice these patterns. She said she wanted to create a book with patterns that readers could see if they cared to look. 

Even with its unique structure, The Luminaries is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, she didn’t plan the story in advance. She would write herself into difficult situations and then see how creatively she could get out of them. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. 

We also talked about her love for TV dramas. I asked if she would be interested in writing for television. She said that could be fun. She spoke enthusiastically about her work and New Zealand. She noticed that being in a different place changes her imagination. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busy cities to be around more people. But for now, New Zealand will still be her home. I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

**Simplified Text:**

When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building acoustic guitars by hand. Jonny loves the guitar and wonders how two pieces of wood can make such beautiful sounds. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to make it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood change the sound of the guitar.

Jonny built his first bass guitar, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job at that time. He also liked painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he went to university to study architecture because he liked design. However, he dropped out halfway through because he felt it wasn’t right for him. He realized that building guitars was like making sculptures, but with sound. He thought it would be a better job because people use the guitars he makes.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows to earn extra money. At first, he sold his guitars for the cost of materials, but as he became known as a good guitar maker, he could charge more. Even now, after almost forty years, he says he is still just getting by. He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the beginning, Jonny worked hard to get known. He went to music festivals on weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his guitars because he didn’t think about money much. Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar makers today in the UK. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. But now, UK-made guitars are respected for their quality.

Jonny thinks new guitar makers should take courses to learn valuable skills. However, he also believes that learning by trying and making mistakes is very important. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. If you make the back of a guitar too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. He says that if you learn from someone else, you might only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, you can learn many different things.

Text: 

When we talk about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a common tradition, and many writers mention the famous saying by Dr. Johnson, an English writer from the 1700s, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This saying is still true today. 

Many people try to explain why the English talk about the weather so much, but they often get it wrong. They think that English people are really interested in the weather itself. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that the English weather is not very interesting. He points out that in England, we do not have extreme weather like tornadoes or big storms, which makes it less exciting.

However, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that the English weather is interesting because it is always changing. He says that even if we do not have big storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be sure what the weather will be like.

I believe that both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point. When English people talk about the weather, they are not really talking about the weather. Instead, these conversations are a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, when someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking about the weather. These phrases are just ways to start a conversation or fill a pause.

Talking about the weather is like a social tool for English people. There are specific situations where we use weather talk. Some people think that English people talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. We usually use weather talk in three situations: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or when there is a pause in the conversation. 

Because of this, it may seem like English people talk about the weather a lot. A conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk, and return to weather talk when there is a silence. This is why many people think that English people are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, even more than going to Spain, Greece, or France. But they really wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt she didn’t have good answers. 

When she could not find a good historical novel about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started a new career as a writer in 2001. She felt that writing was a big change for her. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not so exhausting. My former teaching colleagues are jealous because I still connect with children through my stories,” she said. 

Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. “Many young adult books talk about negative experiences. They are well written, but they are often dark. Other books are total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.” Alice always tried to teach English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy. She loves to see when a child goes from being bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them interested,” she explained.

Alice started writing her first novel because she saw a need for it. She was also inspired by the idea of her two sons leaving home and a suggestion from her head teacher to take a creative writing course. At first, she was surprised. “I had been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me, but I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send the teachers her best piece of writing, which she only learned a few days before leaving. “I sat down at the computer and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby. Three hours and 30 pages later, I sent it in and was accepted right away.”

During the course, other students read her story and gave her great feedback, suggesting she should publish it.
