With only 8,000 report cards showing her writing skills, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. It helped that her husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor. His help in editing the novel was very important. Alice said, “My mother-in-law thinks we are now rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He helps with what I write – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if something isn’t working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would have Jonny in a car and Alistair on a mountain bike, racing against each other in the beautiful and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England. They would race to the same finish line. 

“I’m excited!” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before. The views are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I can stay warm in the car.” Alistair was also excited, but he wore warm cycling clothes, unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt. “Honestly,” Alistair said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway!”

The race began at Semerwater lake and would finish at Fleet Moss, which is the highest road in Yorkshire, about 350 meters up. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill at the start. They quickly shook hands and then started the race. Alistair rode off on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and drove away. The big question was: who would finish first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly went down. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he faced a big problem. A giant tractor came out of a field and blocked the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he said to the cameraman in his car. “If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving. Meanwhile, Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the steep slope, while sheep watched him curiously.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining, he started to ride faster. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The roads in this part of Yorkshire are very old and narrow. He had to drive slowly around a tight corner and through a small stream on the road. After leaving the last village, Jonny was finally on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close they were to each other.

As Jonny drove quickly towards Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and then he had to brake suddenly as he reached the finish line. Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration and shouted, “Yes!” 

A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in his car and got out. “Well done,” he said to Alistair, feeling disappointed. “I’m really sad.”

Text: 

When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, the first thing you notice is the silence. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The beautiful grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowd all make you feel separate from the outside world. This quiet helps my game. The hardest part for me during a match is to focus only on the game and the point I am playing. 

When a point ends, the silence is broken by loud applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching on TV as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach since I was young, taught me that this is the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win.

Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. Losing in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to be there at twenty years old. Federer won easily, but in 2007, I felt completely broken after losing. I knew I could have played better, and it was my mind that let me down. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance to win and you lose it.

Toni, my tough coach, usually does not comfort me, even when I win. But after my loss in 2007, he told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I thought that was my last chance to win. I know that a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big chance slip away in 2007. 

Toni could not take away my sadness, but he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I felt confident that I had learned from my loss. The best sign that I was ready was that I believed I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family and friends, we did not talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already thinking about the game in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that space in my head was mine alone.

Text: 

In early April 1957, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always wanted." She spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Jane Goodall became famous when Britain’s National Geographic Society published articles and made documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. She also wrote popular books, including children's books and the bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century. However, her fame sometimes makes people forget her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. 

Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading scientist because of her important research on chimpanzees. She helped us understand their social and emotional lives. Before her work, people thought wild chimpanzees were very dangerous, and they did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. Goodall discovered that chimpanzees have emotions similar to humans and that they have their own cultural traditions. 

Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," published in 1986, is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her long study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves as humans.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of becoming a biologist. When she was five years old, she disappeared one autumn day. The police and her family searched for her. After a long search, she came back with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she crawled into a henhouse and waited quietly for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

Text: 

In our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of different characters. She sounds like a funny 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, an amusing old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV shows and cartoons. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says. “I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors think they can do funny voices, and some can,” she says. “But it’s more than that. You have to make the script interesting for an audience that can’t see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don’t get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley took a drama course because she wanted to be an actress. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and surprisingly got a big part.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and thought voiceover work might be a good path for her. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult women often do the voices for small boys and girls because their voices are higher than those of men. There are many rules and forms to follow when hiring child actors, which production companies want to avoid. Shirley has learned to make different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are hard because I have to sound excited about something I don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that smiling while talking makes my voice sound happy.” When she works on animation, it feels like a holiday because she enjoys working with other actors.

The competition for voiceover work is tough, and having a good showreel – a recording that shows what she can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has succeeded in her career through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel or practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests going to special workshops that teach different types of voiceover work. She also thinks it’s important to love human sounds. She describes herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing an American voice, for example, I might talk like that for hours or even days after,” she says. “My children are used to me talking in different voices.”

Text: 

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people give up these dreams and choose more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, but some people do just that.

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that needed political cartoons about local issues. I created some ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. The barriers to becoming a cartoonist are low, but it is still a tough job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I take on all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But now, most cartoonists have to be entrepreneurs. This means you not only create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with selling, the better you will do. I have seen cartoonists with average creativity but great business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!

Text: 

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had bought for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar from Japan. I usually hate getting rid of things, so I wondered why I wanted to throw this guitar away. I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said “Yes.” After that, I felt sad about giving it away.

A few months ago, I opened an email that changed my life. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I read an email from a man named Keith Rushton, who restores guitars. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name and address on a label on the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy I almost cried. I would have given him anything, but his price was fair.

I remembered how my dad liked to put name labels on everything I owned, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. But I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar and played easier songs. At that time, punk music was also popular, and anyone could be a rock star, even if they didn’t play well.

When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt amazing. It was smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands just knew what to do. My fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings to play a chord. 

The electric guitar is not really meant to be played alone. Now that I am learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

Text: 

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book called Insomniac, which is about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was the only one talking about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep can affect our minds, bodies, and feelings. Many people who have trouble sleeping understand how important sleep is for our health. It is good that sleep is finally getting more attention. 

But what about dreams? I have not heard much about them in this discussion. We often lose our dreams. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM sleep, or ‘Rapid Eye Movement’ sleep. This is the stage of sleep where we have the most vivid and memorable dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. If a person lives to be 90 years old, they will spend about six or seven years in REM sleep. 

When researchers take away REM sleep from people, they find that the next night, those people have more REM sleep to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM sleep, and many agreed with the famous psychologist Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams helps us understand our minds. However, later studies showed that it is not that simple. Now, researchers focus more on the physical reasons for dreams rather than the psychological ones. 

Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, according to Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of sleep experts, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study that showed actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He believes that the more someone is interested in being creative, the more they use their dreams. 

It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wonder, are only creative people the ones who benefit from their dreams? Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present. Dreams can help us find new patterns and think outside the box. 

For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They come up with unexpected ideas that make sense in a different way. This is what creativity is, according to Stickgold. I find that I write better when I wake up from intense dreams. Even a dream that is troubling or hard to remember can help me think better. On those days, my ideas come out quickly, and I can hardly keep up with my typing. 

I don’t know exactly how it works, but it seems to help. However, creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complicated world, and everyone needs their brains to work well. We all need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Text: 

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and many empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist. She can copy famous paintings from the early 20th century, like those by Impressionist artists, and also works from the 16th century, like Caravaggio. It is surprising that she does not keep any of her own paintings. “I don’t have any of my own around,” Susie says. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted many famous artists’ works, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal the names of most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off their collection. One famous buyer likes to say he has a ‘Van Gogh’ painting, but it is really a ‘Susie Ray Van Gogh’. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s up to them.” Some collectors keep the original painting in a bank safe and show Susie’s copy in their home.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it is important to respect the original artist. However, she puts her own signature on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real painting, and even though she knows people who have done this, she has never wanted to. People who make fake art often get into trouble. Susie is not rich and has had some hard times, but her life is more stable now. She does not want to risk her good reputation with collectors and artists.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after finishing her art degree. She earned very little money for several years. Looking back, she thinks that job helped her learn important skills and gave her a love for plants, even though it was hard to live on that salary. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets about that time, but she is happy to have found a more rewarding job.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw well and represent things accurately. She also emphasizes how much she has studied to do her work. Her training allows her to draw plants, make perfect copies of 15th-century paintings, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art. Now, she focuses on French Impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas being her favorites. 

Susie believes that many people think modern art is easy, but she explains that Impressionists painted quickly and freely, yet they were also very careful. This combination is hard to achieve. Given her skills, it seems strange that Susie does not create her own art. Isn’t art about expressing yourself? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work comes from years of training, and she makes a good living from it. She has tried to create her own art before, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. They were fine, but not better than that. It’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a great chef. Susie is a perfectionist.

Text: 

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything else when she was a racer. Since she was a child, she wanted to be the fastest person on the water. She felt a strong connection with her boats, which took her around the world. When she was back on land, life felt unimportant, and she wanted to be back at sea, challenging nature, even in places that were dangerous for her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her small boat, Kingfisher. She took me into the tiny cabin where she lived for 94 days. She explained how she carefully planned everything, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need. Preparation was very important to her. She proudly showed me her simple food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical supplies. She took great care of her boat because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small and beautiful, but also fragile. A trip to South Georgia, a lonely island in the South Atlantic, changed her perspective. She helped with a bird survey and realized how humans often take what they want from nature and move on. 

When I visited her office, she was finishing a busy call. She told me why we need to act now to protect the planet. “We can’t make more coal, oil, or gas. They are valuable resources that we have only once. We need to find ways to use less,” she said. At first, her message was negative, but she later focused on re-using things, like industrial carpet tiles. 

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories and talking to businesses and governments about our dependence on resources that cannot be replaced. “I may not be an expert,” she said, “but I love learning. The current situation is something I cannot ignore. Sailing felt selfish compared to this work. It’s about finding how I can help the most.”

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people think about a sustainable future. “I miss the adventure of being at sea,” she said. “It is part of who I am. At sea, you feel connected to everything, and you don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on survival and your goals. My new message is not as simple as saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I have done.”

**Simplified Text:**

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore nature, instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he is a teenager.

I spoke to some famous climbers who have climbed Everest. They do not think it is a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They believe that while a young climber might be strong, they may not be emotionally ready. They also think that a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing.

The Romero family has heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know people criticize us, but I don’t want to focus on that. We have a lot to do. I think about the risks, but I believe our experience as climbers will help us. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's dream? Paul says, "This project is not about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought he would do this later in life, but we decided, 'Why not do it now?' We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan why he wants to climb, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal." In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest climber. But now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. This creates a problem for Jordan. Some people think that trying to achieve records takes away the fun of climbing. But if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his journey online, take photos, and give interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

Text: 

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it is likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually do not know who he is. I have just started studying music at university, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you do not know who created the music, you probably do not have any of their recordings. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only about 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. 

So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often complain about our love for TV and video games, blaming them for this problem, but I do not think this is the reason. The truth is that classical music does not attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical music concerts often, but they are not many. Even though I play in an orchestra, I do not really enjoy classical music. I like many different styles, but according to what I have on my computer, I listen to classical music about as much as that 3% figure.

So, why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many changes, can be hard for us. We like to talk, play, and think quickly. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music often talks about things that interest teenagers, while classical music does not have lyrics and can be long.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music you want online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are going to classical concerts now. Maybe, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I do not know why more middle-aged people like classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people say that schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids want to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay after school to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they play it, but it is not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually listen to pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it looked confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” said Bonnie, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” said her mother. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do it. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a big area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking carefully at each one. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, and Bonnie liked that. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride the horse. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” Bonnie was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said happily. “I really mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and a little breeze brushed past her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Text: 

"I’ve met Cody Simpson before, and I have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old from Australia has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? 

Cody says, ‘I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven.’ He remembers that he was swimming and surfing every day, and those activities were very important to him at that time. When he was 13 and in high school, he posted a few videos online. These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans wanted to see more of his videos on social media. So, Cody recorded more videos at home and shared them. The response was amazing.

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on his sport. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. 

He said, ‘It was very difficult for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?’ He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. ‘It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,’ he remembers their shocked faces. ‘I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world.’

So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to another part of the world, giving up one dream to try to make another one come true. His family stays out of the spotlight and does not work directly in his career, but they support him. Cody believes it’s important to have good people around you to stay grounded.

Of course, everyone has doubts. ‘Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, “How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?” My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world and does school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,’ Cody admits. ‘I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.’

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big chance, even when it’s a little scary. ‘Everything happened so fast and unexpectedly,’ Cody says. ‘Now, I am going to countries I never thought I would visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like a dream for many people. But I know it won’t last forever.’"

Text: 

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags last week. I had worked with many people in the town for long hours to help. My grandfather did not pay much attention to my work. 

I looked at the dark water coming from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides of the water, and solid ice further down. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I did not know him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and put on my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Only my grandfather, my mom, and I know about this chain. I also have his diary from that trip, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. 

I patted the chain and went to the kitchen. “Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.” “Thanks, Mom,” I replied. I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. “Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” “Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was clear because I was wearing my wetsuit. Grandpa always gets angry, and it is hard for me to deal with it. “What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. 

My mom came over with a kind smile. “Don’t mind him. He’s…” “...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he has always been like this, but I kept quiet. When I was younger, he was my hero. He showed me pictures of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang on his wall, along with his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay close to him, even though he is grumpy. 

My mom smiled. “At least he is coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It will be warmer in South America,” I said. “If I find sponsors for my trip.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. I stepped into the backyard and hurried to the boathouse.

Text: 

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. “Come with me,” she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was a painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s, but it looked different from his other work and was not finished. “Do you know anything about this?” Mum asked. Jess shook her head. “I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything.” 

Jess looked closely at the painting. There was a river in it, but it was not a river she recognized. It looked like a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was very small, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss. The pale water seemed to lead to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. Jess thought about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. “It has a name.” There was something in her voice that showed her excitement. Jess knew why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: “River Boy.” The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why. 

Then Jess noticed something. She looked at Mum. “There is no boy.” 

“Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it.” 

“Mum! You should have known better.” 

“I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said.” 

Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew Grandpa would say, “It’s not the artist’s job to explain a painting. Each painting has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. Painting is hard work, and I can’t waste time explaining it to everyone.” 

Mum laughed. “Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him.” 

“Inspire?” 

“Someone who gives an artist ideas.” Jess knew what it meant. Grandpa often said it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the inspiration was not helping him that day. He never said it was about her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone influencing someone as strong-willed as Grandpa. 

“He doesn’t need me to inspire him,” she said. “He’s been painting all his life.”

Text: 

This morning, I woke up and accidentally cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I didn’t mean to do it, but it could have happened if I had tripped over the bed while holding Dad’s Stanley knife. The knife might have gone into the carpet by itself. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me often, and I feel unlucky about it.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into my room. My Gran gave me this cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is small, painted white, and has pretty flowers on it. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, but now I keep my shells and fossils there. I was very happy when Gran gave it to me!

The problem is that it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to go in a corner. My bedroom is the smallest in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. There are two corners in my room. My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet in the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. 

Then I thought, if I can’t cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet instead. It seemed like a good solution. Dad always tells us to “think outside the box,” and that is what I was trying to do!

Text: 'The novel ‘The Borrowers’ is about a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They borrow things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people’s expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should be. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn’t want to be told I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans', which made filming more difficult. 

The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. When filming the human world around the Borrowers, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans! We only raised the cameras for special shots. 

One big challenge was making sure the shadows looked right when we combined the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we did it. The only set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was very strange. I remember the coins we used; they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because the crew laughed so much. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary that they didn’t need to act. It was also important to me to get the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they looked like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the leading actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look – I drew 2,000 by the end. They weren’t perfect, but they worked. We didn’t have enough money for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – once I filmed a whole scene and then realized there was no film in the camera! But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series was successful in showing the magic of the books.'

Text: 

My mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there aren’t any. I know that soon there will be attention on me. There will be fake smiles, new friends who want something from me, like free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet normal kids. I want to meet kids with regular parents, like a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so cool.

I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. She seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types my last name on her computer. That’s good because not many people know my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she says. Then she gives me my schedule. My first class is English Literature. Great! I like English. But I will be late because it’s in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly trying to find my classes.

When I get to the door, I hear the teacher calling names. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip into the room quietly and sit at the back. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. No one will suspect me! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with flowers on them. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she says. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After that, she lets us talk to each other! All teachers should do this.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few choices. Should I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I say what my dad thinks? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. It has energy, color, and culture.” I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose a studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to move,” I tell her. Yes, it’s better to lie. “What does he do?” she asks. Everyone will find out soon, but I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Great!

Text: 

Today, American teenage girls are expected to do a lot. They should be the president of the Student Council, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in school. Being a teenager in America means you cannot just go to school and be average; you need to be ambitious. Many adults forget how much pressure teenagers feel. They have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and they also want to have a social life. 

Teenager Kristen Loose says that even with all these stresses, people still have negative ideas about teenagers. Some think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and only care about themselves. While some teenagers may fit these stereotypes, Kristen believes it is not fair to label all teenagers this way. She says many people think teenagers spend all their time on their phones and watching TV. Kristen admits she often has her phone nearby, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. 

Today, students need to be connected to the world and reachable all the time, which can look like an addiction to their phones. With smartphones and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they can listen to language lessons. Schoolwork now takes up a lot of their time, even outside of school. Many teenagers wake up around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often go to bed after midnight. They have a busy schedule with school, activities, family duties, and homework, and they usually get less sleep than they need. 

The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are tired. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week, which is not much when there are 168 hours in total. She does not waste her free time on social media or TV; instead, she spends it on volunteer work. 

Lindamarie believes that many people think teenagers only care about themselves, but she loves volunteering and making a positive difference in her school and community. In the future, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to prove people wrong and make the world a better place. There will always be new students who are ready to take on the world before they finish school.

**Simplified Text:**

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US. This town is mostly surrounded by wild nature, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In the last few years, this small group has sent over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers join. 

I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to try to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright light. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the lunch box, there was a camera, a tool to measure height, and a thermometer to check the temperature as the balloon went up. They also put two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to help find it later. 

A gas tank, given by a supporter from another state, was used to fill the balloon with gas, making it grow to the size of a small car. An older boy drove seven hours to get the gas tank. “I didn’t really mind,” he said. For kids in this club, this is normal. Finally, it was time for the balloon to go up. “Five, four, three, two, one,” they counted down, and the balloon started to rise. Some of them ran and followed its path with bright flashlights until they could no longer see it in the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder. Then the balloon disappeared into the night.

After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside and looked at the clear sky, which was surprising because it was only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” said one girl quietly. “I know,” whispered another. Suddenly, a meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, and the balloon got bigger until it popped with a loud noise. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recovering the lunch box is a big part of the program,” said the group’s leader. They had lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us know the landscape better,” he added.

This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students know the Eastern Sierra well,” their leader said. “What seems wild to some is normal for others.” 

In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. The camera did not record any shooting stars. This was a little disappointing, but it gave them a chance to talk about how atmospheric waves work above mountains. It was also another adventure story to share with anyone who asked.

Text: 

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. It happened by chance. "My younger brother was really into dinosaurs, which I didn’t care about at all. I helped him with a science project, and when I read an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology, I was amazed. I knew I wanted to pursue this field."

I asked her how she got support because Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people. "I remember meeting my first professional palaeontologist," she laughs. "His name was Matt Cornelius, and he was already famous, even though he was young. I was very nervous, even though he was known to be friendly. I worried he would think I was just an annoying kid asking too many questions. But I felt better when he was patient and listened to me."

I wanted to know what she thought about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe frowned for a moment. "I have to say that movies like Jurassic Park, which show dinosaurs with special effects, have made many people interested in dinosaurs. But they don’t really show Palaeontology well. I find it annoying that we are often shown as strange geniuses or awkward people who can’t talk to others. Movies don’t show what our daily work is really like."

I asked her to explain her job. "My job is very varied. I spend a lot of time digging up dinosaur bones, but I also work in laboratories, studying fossils and writing scientific papers. Sometimes, if I have time, I also explain scientific findings to the public. I think it is important to help people understand science better. There are many misunderstandings about it. I want to reach out to young people because it is important for them to learn about science. Talking about dinosaurs can get children excited about nature and help them understand other areas of science."

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to help show dinosaurs correctly on screen. She says the makers of the show knew what they were doing, and she was there to give advice if needed. "I had an easy time because there was not much I needed to change, like making sure the dinosaurs were the right size and shape. I mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived at the same time. We attracted audiences of all ages because we have learned so much about dinosaurs recently. The dinosaurs in this show are very different from those in movies like Jurassic Park. They look much more realistic."

I asked Chloe why she thinks dinosaurs still fascinate us and why research continues. "I think they appeal to our natural curiosity. We are drawn to things that are new and exciting. In a world that feels smaller, dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to discover. Palaeontology is like time travel."

Text: 

I want to say something important about traveling by car with your family. Even if you are six years old, you know that you are not “there yet” when you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” When you finally arrive, it is not “there” anymore; it is “here.” So, if you think you might be “there,” you should ask, “Are we here yet?” 

I believe that no one wants to be “there yet” more than parents who hear this question many times during long car trips. Think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while looking at the beautiful views outside the window. In the front seat, your mom or dad is there to give you juice boxes and cookies, change the radio, and make sure everything goes well.

But sometimes, things can get crazy in the car. For example, my younger brother, Tim, often does something annoying, like putting his foot on my side of the seat. I don’t like that, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, we are fighting, and our parents have to separate us while driving. They tell Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This helps for a little while, and we can enjoy the beautiful scenery again.

Later, when I try to read, I feel a breeze on my arm. The window is closed, so I wonder where it is coming from. Tim is next to me, breathing on me. He is not touching me, so he thinks it is okay. This makes me angry, and the fighting starts again. Our parents yell, and the car swerves. But after a while, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he often says, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” But we are still on the highway, going fast. Then he says, “Oh, maybe we’re not there yet.” This makes us quiet for a bit. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids. So remember: if your mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is: no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using their phones or other devices. She believes that people should be together and talk to each other.

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by a German designer named Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources with each other. Everyone stays involved and feels part of the game until the end. 

Later, cooperative games were created, where all players work together to win or lose as a team. One popular cooperative game is Pandemic, designed by Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players must work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the famous book. He remembers feeling scared and excited while playing it with friends. He wanted to create a game that made people feel good, whether they won or lost.

Leacock has loved board games since he was a child. He often felt disappointed when games did not meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he tried to make better games using the pieces from the ones they played. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up game improved game design even more. Leacock explains that it has a lot of storytelling, similar to video games, where players develop characters and the story changes.

The rise of video games has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games too. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says that everyone has at least one game on their phone. 

For a while, video games allowed people to interact physically, like at arcades or when playing together in the same room. But as video games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This made some people want to play games with others who were physically present. 

In John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just fun. In our online world, games are now something to share in person, and this trend is likely to continue.

**Simplified Text:**

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that hard work and not giving up are very important in the music business, even if your career starts slowly. He says his mother was a great singer and helped him learn to play the guitar. The only radio he listened to at home was a local station for older people, which influenced his music as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song.

Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the music room at school learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.” At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not want to make a career in music.

Jamie remembers going to his parents and telling them he wanted to be a musician. He had been writing lyrics during his economics lessons and playing the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he got signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, the record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend.

In the end, he became more successful as a songwriter than as a performer. After a tough time with a record label in the UK, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. He did not become famous right away. He said, “I feel like I have been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my career, but as a writer, I have been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he found success. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists.

Sometimes, he has to explain to the artists he helps that wanting to write popular songs is okay. He asks them, “Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He believes they should aim to write songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well. It is nice to hear someone in pop music talk openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he knows he has a talent for writing number one songs. Instead of trying to please others, he focuses on his work. He says, “When I go into the studio, we need to write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what’s cool. We want to write great modern pop songs.”

**Simplified Text:**

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, do not know him because we do not watch videos of people doing tricks on bikes. He is called a "street trials cyclist." This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another strange place. These jumps are filmed and shared online.

On the day I interview him, we meet in a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all know who he is, and some older people come to tell him he is "an absolute legend." After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was unsure about him, but I am impressed by his bravery and creativity. Before each jump, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I cannot believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems uninterested and a bit sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he does not like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to connect with fans. He prefers to focus on doing his stunts rather than talking about them.

Tony thinks that social media and new camera technology help him earn money from his hobby. He says, "Sometimes I feel like everyone is filming themselves or looking at screens, and I don’t always like that." However, he is not unhappy. He makes a good living from his videos, which is different from how it used to be for people in his sport.

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy obstacles. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, "People who say this may care, but they do not understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and do not know much about the sport. They do not see that I get advice from experts to reduce risks." 

Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, "People are different. Some are not scared, and they should not do these sports. It is smart to know the dangers. I can feel fear but find a way to overcome it. I am not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around for a while to get ready before trying a new jump. I know I must stay calm before I jump. If I focus completely, I will be fine."

Text: 

Television presenter Helen Skelton has done many dangerous challenges for charity. These include running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon river in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire. This wire was 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her keep her balance, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found out that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” said Helen. “I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill. Then I did an hour of exercises, and another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy. Helen controlled her nerves by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterwards. “I’m glad it’s over!” However, this experience has not stopped Helen from planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a trip around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-fashioned bicycle with one big wheel and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes. I decided to see the world by bike.” 

Jeff did not want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. He thought the most interesting bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, when he had to stop because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The best part of his trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more surprised people were by his bike.

His worst experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine. He had no money for a hospital or to go home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

Text: "I work at a university in the US with my team. We are learning about water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’. This tool helps us see the ducks in the dark! We are worried about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are not sure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but we don’t know what they do at night because we didn’t have the right equipment. The new scope will give us clear pictures, even when there is no moon. This will help us learn more and make better choices about how to protect their habitat.

Our work is very hard. There are four of us, and we each work six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some locations and write down what I see. The weather has not been easy – some nights are warm, but most of the time it is wet. It is very quiet, so I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. I enjoy this challenge, especially when I think about the summer. In summer, we will spend hours in a laboratory looking at our results together. It will be hard to be inside, but it is important to do this work. I wouldn’t change it for anything!"

Text: "When I tell people what my job is, they often can't believe it. But I’m serious! I spend my days at work eating chocolate! Tasting chocolate is very important to make sure that customers get the best quality chocolate from my company. Every week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate, from our factory. I have to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for the chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I make. I also share samples with my colleagues! My kitchen has many machines and ingredients to work with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel to buy our raw materials. This can be hard because I have a young family. But I love the variety in my job, even more than the chocolate itself!

People often ask me if I get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never wanted to stop eating it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!"

Text: 

Have you ever thought about what it is like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place that teaches young people circus skills. She says that the course is popular because it teaches many skills. Students learn to juggle, throw and catch things like balls or even fire, and they also learn trapeze, which means flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

The course lasts for one year, and students slowly take more risks in each class. Parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. Sophia explains, “To have a career in the circus, performers need to do different things. It is important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of this job is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important. Circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and always want to improve their skills. 

People often think that circus performers get hurt a lot or that they only work for a short time each year. But the real challenge is thinking about the future because you can only travel and perform while you are young. After that, you need to think about other options.” The course also teaches business planning. Many former students start their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that this is not a job for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It is also very competitive, but it is a lot of fun!”

Text: "You may not know her name or face, but you have probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. This means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not good enough to be lead singers, but that is not true. They often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry!

Mariam says, 'What I love about my job is that when I go into the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing. It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it is a funny song for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what the producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do my job!'

'To do my work well, I need excellent musical skills and the ability to learn quickly. There is often no written music to follow. I will never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are already long!'

'One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range is best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can see how to make it better.'"

Text: 'Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she created a successful business selling ‘satchels’ - a traditional bag used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular with many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie thought about different business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She wanted to make the right choice. When she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her. Julie said, “Many people said there was no demand for them – but I was sure.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never worked before but was good at business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 

Julie didn’t know much about fashion blogs, but they helped her succeed. At first, she sold about one satchel a week. To create interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers and hoped they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her satchels grew, as did the speed at which her company made them. Now, Julie enjoys waiting to see which celebrity is seen with a satchel! While other companies spend money on online ads, she uses the internet community for ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. 

There was a difficult time when another company copied Julie’s design to sell similar bags. Because of this, she now makes sure she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often say there is a positive feeling in her offices – people enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it is the team that makes it a special place.'

Text: 

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose what to do in their free time. Vicky liked to play many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, so it was hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork.

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started to compete. Vicky thought this looked exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so it was easy for her to go to training after school.

Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won many competitions. When she was 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, “For years, I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it. When the excitement goes away, there’s no point in continuing. Luckily, I found a new job.”

Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. She said, “We work with young people who have never enjoyed sports. The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job and helps young people feel part of a group.”

The charity uses famous people to promote their work. Vicky said, “Some people think having a celebrity support a charity is not always good. They believe celebrities do it for their own benefit, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.”

Text: 

Ana Ronson is a singer-songwriter from Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, there was always music in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of people was at school. She was very nervous, and her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to help her feel more confident. After some time in the club, she sang happily with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term.

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. Ana wrote her first song, called Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed writing so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest student, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her, so she wrote a song called Something to Say about how this made her feel. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was happy when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics.

Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, flew from the other side of Ireland to ask Ana to join his company. At first, she was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. But Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. All the tickets sold out quickly, and it was a wonderful evening.
