Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments because she feels she has more to say then. One of her favorite songs is Decision, which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how sad it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on a wonderful trip. I traveled by boat on a guided group tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, but I do not share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit this area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew it was where our great-grandparents lived before they moved to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him, and he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we were going to. But luckily, the weather forecast for our trip was good. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry said he would take care of everything, so I felt better.

When we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our supplies into small boats, and started our journey. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast now. On our first morning, the only living creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the morning fog made it hard to see far. I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t know. It was nice to forget about time and just enjoy the day. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. Even though the beds were hard, it felt relaxing.

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. I didn’t want to go back to normal life. But I knew I would miss my family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!

Text: "My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that watching so many matches would make me love basketball, but it did the opposite. I liked telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often took a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. My sports teacher saw my height and asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training, but I thought I needed to get better before playing in a real match. The teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I was in a game against another school. My parents came to watch, which made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before I moved to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy living far from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with my friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t a big change for me. In the end, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it."

Text: "Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After thinking about different options, I trained to be a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed giving tours. I saw the city I had lived in my whole life from the tourists' perspective, and it felt new every time!

After I finished my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I looked into it, I found out that I needed to know a lot more than I had learned. All tour guides in Chicago must answer many questions about the city, including local history, architecture, and public transport rules. After several months of hard work, I got my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent tour guide.

Being a tour guide is not just about knowing facts or keeping track of the group. You also need other skills. You should be entertaining and tell interesting stories. Most importantly, you must be able to handle unexpected situations, like if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour, not hear about problems.

I need to make sure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might leave a bad review online. Like most tour guides, I know that good reviews are very important because they attract more customers. That’s why I try to make my tours fun and stress-free. I believe that my enthusiasm and energy help me get good reviews, and many visitors recommend my tours to others coming to Chicago."

Text: "My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. She is five years younger than me, but we get along well. We went to help at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people take care of sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was not sure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. In the end, we had nothing to worry about. 

One of our main jobs at the sanctuary was to collect food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it hard work, but I thought it was worth it to see the elephants enjoy their food. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I had a lot of fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By the light of the moon, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, which was small, but we chose to do this because Josie did not want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and did not have meat, which we do not like. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie does not often talk about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I think she might be a little upset with herself for not enjoying her time more because she missed her friends. But when she thinks back, she can see how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she will go back one day – I know I will!"

Text: "My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to people for their homes or friends, but to many different customers. Hotels and offices often buy flowers for their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for businesses to use in their advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of what we did.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep, and my friends think I am crazy, but I love what I do. It is often cold and dark at that time, but I don’t let it bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were buying for myself, I would probably choose only pink flowers because it is my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like is not always what my customers want. Not all flowers are available all year, so sometimes I cannot find what customers want.

I don’t like arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it is part of my job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and prepare vases with the flowers I bought. Then we create flower bunches and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to think again about what they want. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy finding the best flowers for the money someone wants to spend. That is what you have to do when you sell things – I wouldn’t want any other job!"

Text: "My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films I want to see, and many films for kids on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I felt something was missing – I wanted to talk about a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema. Instead, we choose a different place in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was great! Some places we use are free because the owners sell snacks during the film, so we can keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs – we do not want to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier for us, especially now that we have our own good equipment. We can also see how many tickets we have sold online, so we do not worry about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us at the end how much they enjoyed it, it feels wonderful. Our website has helped a lot, and we are now in touch with other film clubs around the country. We have visited them to see how they do things, but it is always nice to return to our own club! We have also started a blog because we know that many people look online for information about films instead of reading local papers. We have tried putting up some posters in cafés, but nothing is as good as people telling their friends about us. The audience loves the special activities we have with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed."

Text: "Taking photographs was my favorite activity when I was a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to make my hobby more special. So, I decided to start a personal project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many other young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began.

After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that many people liked my photos. I enjoyed taking pictures of many different things. Then, someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and started to focus on nature, especially birds and the sky. Most of my photos were black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they took color photos. Sometimes, I doubted my project and almost gave up, but I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style.

One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges told me I won first prize. I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good, and I could work as a professional photographer. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice of career."

Text: "I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping and sailing, and learn skills like public speaking. In the NYC, you can do different activities to challenge yourself and learn something new. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you finish each level, you get a certificate.

When I first joined, my leader suggested that I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was not sure it was a good idea because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy then, and the other children already had their own friends, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. 

When I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I had made good friendships with the children. Now, I go there for about four hours a week, and I always look forward to it. Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about my future job before starting at the club. This has been my favorite part of the NYC, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have several NYC certificates now, and one of them is for camping!"

I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort, which is about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved snowboarding and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and in the end, I did well. After that, I quickly fell in love with the sport and got better at it. I began competing when I was ten years old. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for snowboarding and winning has grown as I got older. This helps me to work harder.

I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well. For example, I became the first female to get a perfect score of 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I could do the jumps that got me this score until I tried. This achievement made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I focus on training and studying when there is no snow. I train every day, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends during this time. It helps me deal with not being able to do what I love and what I am good at.

I think carefully about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I also want to have another option in case I don’t become a professional snowboarder or if I get hurt. I am thinking about becoming a doctor if I can find time to study while being active. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.

Text: "When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could only have it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am thankful to my parents for making me do that because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I thought it would be hard, but it was easier than I expected. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me how to make something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family. They said they liked them, but I wasn’t sure if they really meant it. I wanted to know if other people would like them too, so I rented a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewellery to take home. Soon, we got calls from people all over the country who wanted to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just me and my mum at the stall! That made me realize my business could work, so I decided to create a website. Since then, I have made a lot of money from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall. It has been a lot of fun!"

Text: 

When Janine Stuart was 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became very popular. Being Amelia is partly about Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine said, “Because my father’s job made us move around a lot, I learned to make new friends easily. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia’s experiences in a new school. Some funny parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I am an only child, I had to use my imagination to describe that.”

Janine started writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to write. The year before, she won a short story competition on a young writers’ website. That’s why, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were excited to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was in bookshops.

One review of Being Amelia says that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentions that even though Janine is young and her novel is not very long, she is a better writer than many other bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being a famous writer: “At first, I hid when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I will have interesting things to write about!”

Text: "My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. My father was invited to be the manager of the castle. He works for a group that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was happy to get this job, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We thought the castle might not be as comfortable as our warm home across the water, and there was no school on the island.

After we moved, we quickly got used to living on the island. The castle is not very beautiful, but our apartment is comfortable. In the summer, the island is lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we only see the other families who live here, and there are not many teenagers, which I had hoped for. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, and this can be hard work.

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to going on stormy days when there are big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also found out that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry!

We often see amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then it can be sunny again in a few hours. This still feels amazing to me, even after living here for a long time. We do have terrible storms sometimes, and I wonder if the castle is strong enough to stay safe. But I remind myself that it has been here for hundreds of years, and it is still standing!"

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural homes. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different bird species apart and where to find the best places to see them. It was amazing! After we returned home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am almost there. On family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! 

I have been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I would see my 200th species. I was not too disappointed when it didn’t happen because I learned that you need to be patient with this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers liked it and said it looked like a fun hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I felt nervous just before I walked onto the stage. I knew what to say and had some notes, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year!

I am lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think about becoming birdwatchers, but there are many birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to cost a lot of money.

Text: "I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other boys and girls. I loved it, and after some time, I became a good player. My family knew I often liked new hobbies but then stopped doing them, so they thought I would do the same with football. But I didn’t. I even dreamed of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee saw that I was a good player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager liked me, and I started training with a big club when I was 13 years old. I got much better after that. Still, some people were not sure I would become a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach told me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s important matches earlier than I thought I would! I ran very hard because I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. Then, by chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a big crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my team carried me around the field. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and to let them meet other players in my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and encourage them to think they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – there will be good times, but also some bad times. I have had very few bad times, so I feel lucky!"

Text: 

In recent years, there has been an interesting change in education in the UK and around the world. Schools and universities are encouraging new students to get involved in research early in their studies. This shows that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists, but is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are important not only for studying but also for jobs, as they help us think about the world and how we do our work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Making knowledge starts with asking questions instead of just accepting things. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can be seen in two ways. On one side, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts. On the other side, there is everyday research that involves asking thoughtful questions about issues and making practical suggestions. Most students have done some form of research before. You have likely done research for school projects or when you needed to find information for personal interests, like planning a holiday or fixing something at home.

In college and higher education, it is important to have a curious mind, identify problems, and critically explore information. You are expected to create your own responses and knowledge. Some students may find this difficult because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and students are taught to listen to teachers and texts without questioning them. However, in many places like the UK, US, and Europe, it is important to question established knowledge and those who claim to be experts.

This process of questioning and creating knowledge can be challenging. Critical thinking is very important in research. The research done by others can help us as students and in our future jobs, but we should not just repeat what we read. We need to think about it, test it, and check if it makes sense and is supported by evidence. We should not blindly accept facts and information from others without thinking critically about them.

**Simplified Text:**

Cities have always been important places for ideas and discussions. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artist Pablo Picasso discussed art in cafés. However, living in a city can be difficult. The same cafés in London that encouraged conversation also helped spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. 

Today, cities are known for creativity, but they can also feel overwhelming. Scientists are studying how city life affects our brains, and their findings are surprising. While we have always known that city life can be tiring, new research shows that living in a city can actually make it harder for us to think clearly. One reason for this is the lack of nature in cities. Studies show that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains relax and work better.

For the first time in history, more people live in cities than in rural areas. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into busy cities with many strangers. This crowded environment can affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. When we walk down a busy street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people walking, cars, and confusing street layouts. These small tasks can tire us out because our brains have to work hard to focus. 

Natural places, on the other hand, do not require as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He believed that being in nature can help our brains recover. Natural settings have things that catch our attention without causing stress, unlike loud noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape designers warned about the negative effects of city life and looked for ways to bring nature into cities. Parks, like Central Park in New York, give people a break from city life. A well-designed park can help our brains feel better in just a few minutes. While people have tried many ways to improve brain function, such as energy drinks or changing office designs, walking in nature seems to be one of the best solutions.

Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Research shows that the same crowded features of cities that can make it hard to focus also help create new ideas. The close social interactions in cities are important for creativity. Just like the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of modern cities can also lead to innovation. 

The challenge is to find ways to reduce the stress of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, there will always be times when people feel tired of nature and want to go back to the city.

**Simplified Text:**

Where should we look for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to show this. However, I believe that studying the mind should not only focus on what is inside our heads. There is a lot of evidence from history that shows that objects, as well as our brains, are important for our thinking. 

For example, tools, jewelry, drawings, and writing have all played a role in how humans have developed and how we think. Therefore, what is outside our heads might also be part of our minds. It is easy to think of the mind and the brain as the same thing. Most of what we know about the mind comes from studying people without the things they usually use. This is useful for scientists who study the brain, but it often ignores that much of our thinking happens with the help of things around us. 

I do not want to say that the brain is not important, but I want to show that the mind is more than just the brain. It is better to think that human intelligence goes beyond our skin and includes culture and objects. This is where my new idea, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how objects can help us think, like when we make numbers from clay or use a stone to create a tool. It also studies how these ways of thinking have changed over time and what that means for us.

This idea helps us understand what minds are and how they work by looking at how objects help our thinking. For example, think of a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick shows how minds and objects can work together. The stick helps the blind person feel and understand their surroundings. The brain even treats the stick as part of the body. 

This example reminds us that human intelligence can change a lot when we use new tools. I see the human mind as something that is always changing and developing. It is important to remember that, no matter what form the “stick” takes in our history – from early stone tools to smartphones – its main purpose is to help us explore and understand the world. 

For humans, tools are used to satisfy our curiosity. This special ability to engage with objects is why humans create things more than any other species, and how these things shape our minds. I call this idea metaplasticity – our minds can change and grow as we interact with the world around us. I want to bring the importance of objects back into how we think about the mind. MET offers a new way to understand how different tools, from ancient hand-axes to modern smartphones, have helped define and change who we are and how we think. Technology that changes our minds may sound futuristic, but humans have been using it since we first appeared.

Text: 

Photography is one of the most important inventions that has changed how we see the world. This is especially true in the United States, where photography became a big part of culture. It is used in many ways, from science and industry to art and entertainment. Historians believe that photography is one of the greatest contributions of the US to the visual arts. 

Photography became popular in the mid-19th century. There are several reasons why this new art form was so appealing. First, photography is a mechanical process, which matched the growing interest in technology. Just like steam power and railroads made communication and travel easier, photography brought images of the world into people's homes quickly. 

Second, the camera became a popular tool for people to show their identity. It allowed individuals and families to create images that represented them, even if those images were idealized. Third, photography's realistic style matched the trend of realism in US art, which focused on everyday life. 

Every photograph draws attention to something specific. It shows what the photographer wants us to see. Because photographs are made by machines, they are records of events, people, and things. This gives them a sense of objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by a person, it also carries the photographer's point of view. 

People often think they understand a photograph because they recognize the subject. This is why photography is often called a "universal language." But the meaning of a photograph can be more complicated. The things we see in a photograph do not always speak for themselves. The way we understand an image can change based on its context, like a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery. 

To understand a photograph's history, we need to consider why the photographer took it and how people first saw it. The same image can have different meanings depending on where and when it is viewed. 

In recent years, artists have started to use photographs in their work more openly. For example, Andy Warhol used photographs in his paintings and silk screens. Today, photography is seen as an important part of art, working alongside painting to help us understand representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and doctor, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition helps us understand psychology even today. Everyone has a mental life, which means we have some idea of what it is, but it can be hard to study. James was especially interested in human psychology, which he believed included basic elements like thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and how we know about these things. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not match scientific facts.

Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We act like amateur psychologists when we share our opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing works or why people behave in certain ways. Problems can arise when two people understand things differently. Formal psychology tries to provide methods to find out which explanations are most likely correct in different situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between our personal thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

Psychology, as William James defined it, is about the mind and brain. While psychologists study the brain, they do not yet fully understand how it works in relation to our feelings, hopes, and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and making educated guesses about what happens inside us.

A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but we cannot see the mind in the same way we can see a machine. We can only understand it indirectly through behavior. Studying psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle; it requires careful observation and logical thinking. Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to change the processes it studies. When psychologists achieve these goals, they can help us understand our experiences and improve people's lives.

Psychological research has been useful in many areas, such as teaching children to read better, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings when they are emotionally distressed. Although people have discussed psychological questions for centuries, scientific investigation of these questions has only happened in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, which means looking at one's own thoughts and feelings, to find answers. While this method is still interesting, it has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton said, it only shows a small part of what the brain does automatically. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to turning up the gas to see how darkness looks. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than just on their own experiences.

Text: 

In a storehouse in a simple business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum shows products that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. It is owned by a company called GfK. The owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product has its own sad story about the designers and marketers who created it. 

What is surprising is that this museum exists as a business. Many companies do not keep samples of their failed products. Each week, business executives visit the museum, showing how rare it is for companies to think about their failures. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing worker, wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failed ones. He began collecting every new item he could find in the 1960s. He did not realize that most products fail. Because he collected so many new products, most of them turned out to be unsuccessful.

Today’s culture of optimism may explain why many products ended up in the museum. Each product likely went through meetings where people did not see that it would fail. Even if they did, marketers might spend more money on a bad product to try to make it sell. They often do not investigate what went wrong, and everyone involved may choose to forget about it.

This focus on being positive is also common in the self-help field. One popular idea is "positive visualization," which means that if you imagine good outcomes, they are more likely to happen. Some scientists, like Tali Sharot, have found that our minds may be naturally inclined to see things positively, which can help us survive. However, people who are well-balanced may not have a clear view of their true abilities compared to those who are depressed.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied how thinking positively about the future affects motivation. They found that spending time imagining good outcomes can actually reduce people's motivation to reach their goals. For example, people who thought about having a great week at work ended up achieving less.

Another psychologist, Carol Dweck, believes that how we view failure is connected to our beliefs about ability. People with a "fixed mindset" think that ability is something you are born with. They find failure very scary because it shows they did not meet expectations. For example, a sports star who thinks he is a natural talent may not practice enough and then fail. 

On the other hand, people with a "growth mindset" see failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles grow stronger when they are pushed to their limits. Having a growth mindset is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.

**Simplified Text:**

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is this? Many people think they know the answer, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main reasons for this are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players perform their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. At the same time, people who invest money in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

What about the fans? Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some of their home games far away, like in Asia, to reach more fans? It would matter to British fans who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. Fans often think that the order of events explains what happens. For example, when a team plays well, the home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal. Fans remember cheering and then seeing a goal, but they forget the times when cheering did not lead to a goal.

There is one idea that seems to be supported by science. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct their noise at the referee. In a famous study, referees watched a game with crowd noise and another group watched in silence. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees try to avoid making calls that would upset the home crowd.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in many sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in England, home teams won about 70% of the points, but now they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, traveling was difficult, but now players travel in comfort. Also, stadiums today are more similar and less unique than before.

Despite these changes, the reason for home advantage still varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because baseball is more about individual players, while team sports like basketball rely on teamwork. Playing at home helps build confidence among teammates.

Another interesting point is about players’ testosterone levels. Studies show that players have higher testosterone levels before home games, which may connect to a natural desire to protect their home field. In some recent Rugby World Cup games, underdog teams won at home against stronger teams, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, “It’s the law of the jungle out there.”

Text: "‘The more I practice, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player many years ago. This saying is famous among athletes and their coaches. It is easy to understand why. Many people argue about who first said this quote, and its meaning is not clear. Player did not mean 'lucky' in a real way; he was being ironic. His real message was: ‘The more I practice, the better I get.’ 

This idea connects to a big question: Is talent something you are born with, or can you develop it through practice? Many believe that practice is more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson is known for saying that you need 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in any field. This idea has been popularized in books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers and Talent Is Overrated. These books suggest that practice is the most important factor in becoming an expert.

However, author David Epstein argues that this idea is not always true. He points out a problem in studies about successful people: they often only look at those who are already excellent. Epstein asks if there are other ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not. He travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden, to find answers. 

In Alaska, he learns that the drive and desire of sled dogs might be important in a tough race. This suggests that some traits might be connected to genetics, not just practice. Epstein believes that both nature (genes) and nurture (environment) are important for elite athletes. He does not ignore the role of training or support. For example, he thinks that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in the world.

Epstein also discusses race and gender in sports. He asks an important question: ‘If only practice matters, why do we have separate competitions for men and women?’ Sometimes, the best questions are the most obvious."

**Simplified Text:**

A recent international report shows that many children living in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so sad? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, looking at screens like televisions and computers. They have lost touch with nature, such as forests, mountains, and rivers. She believes this is a big part of the problem.

A follow-up study talked to some children to understand their feelings better. The study found that many children do not want more technology; they would be happier if they could go outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their own childhoods fondly, saying they enjoyed playing outside, swimming, and exploring. They think this was better and healthier than the lives of children today. However, they often forget that they created the rules that keep their children indoors, worrying about safety.

Griffiths’ book has many strong opinions. She discusses how parents’ fears about dangers outside make them keep their children at home. This fear helps companies that sell toys and gadgets, as they want to keep children entertained indoors. She also talks about how some people give medicine to children who are restless or make them wear goggles for playground games. It is unclear how common these rules are, but Griffiths expresses her anger about them.

While her ideas are interesting, Griffiths sometimes goes too far. She compares how we treat children today to racism, which seems extreme. She has a very romantic view of children, believing they are naturally good and creative. However, this view may not match reality, especially when dealing with energetic young children.

One important idea in the book is that children should be allowed to explore and take risks. Griffiths thinks children need to experience small accidents to learn how to handle bigger dangers later. However, she does not explain how to create safe situations for these small accidents. Also, not all children want to explore the wild. Some are shy or prefer to stay at home. Perhaps the real problem is that we try to make all children fit into the same mold, whether we keep them inside or push them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill does not come only from school. Many problems in life cannot be solved with complicated formulas or answers we memorize in school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from life experiences. For children, these experiences often happen through play.

My recent research focuses on how important play is for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young. Those who have more to learn tend to play more. For example, carnivores (meat-eaters) play more than herbivores (plant-eaters) because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates, like monkeys and apes, play more than other mammals because they need to learn more and rely less on instincts.

Children, who have a lot to learn, play more than any other young primates when they are allowed to. Play is a natural way for both adults and mammals to learn. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling their emotions.

Creativity is very important for success in today’s world. We do not need people who just follow instructions or do simple calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can help people think ahead and find solutions, we will have a strong workforce. But this requires creative thinking, which comes from a playful mind.

Many adults we call geniuses keep their childlike ability to play and think creatively throughout their lives. For example, Albert Einstein said that school almost took away his interest in math and physics, but he found it again after leaving school. He called his creative work "combinatorial play." He imagined chasing a sunbeam and thought about what would happen if he caught it.

We cannot teach creativity, but school can sometimes take it away by focusing on questions that have only one right answer. More importantly, children need to learn how to get along with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children naturally want to play with each other, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality, which they will need later in life.

Play is voluntary, which means players can choose to stop. If you cannot stop, it is not play. Players know they must keep each other happy to continue the game. This freedom makes play a very democratic activity.

However, school has become more difficult. There are fewer breaks, more homework, and more pressure for high grades. Outside of school, organized sports have taken the place of spontaneous games. "Play dates" with adults supervising have replaced unsupervised play in neighborhoods. Adults often feel they must step in instead of letting children solve their own problems.

These changes have happened slowly but have had a big impact. They are caused by many social factors, such as parents' fears, warnings from experts about dangers, less connected neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other.

Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They should be allowed to play and explore so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

**Simplified Text:**

In many countries, more and more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to connect directly with potential employers. This is easier than the old way of standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, using social media can also lead to mistakes.

For example, a young job seeker in the US tried to connect with a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts, and the job seeker thought she could help him. But the executive was upset by his request. She refused to connect with him and sent a rude message that became very popular online. Many people were shocked by her message, and she might regret how she responded. However, if this incident makes young people think more carefully about using social media for work, it could help them.

Social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. This is surprising because social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of young people's lives for years. When older generations were teenagers, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to show off and be creative. You could have long conversations online and then ignore those people at school. You could also change how you looked to others by choosing different pictures or songs for your profile.

But using social media for professional reasons is very different. Some young people do not see this difference. They learned to be bold and confident online, which can lead to problems. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you will impress employers on LinkedIn. Young people need to understand that the rules of social networking have changed, and they must meet employers' expectations to succeed in their careers.

One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too casual in their messages and seem arrogant. This makes older generations think young people feel entitled. In reality, many young people are struggling to find jobs, which is why they are using social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be good employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing some research or helping in another way. This will give you a better chance of getting a helpful response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone polite to make a good impression. Remember, social media can help you make important connections, but you need to use it carefully to avoid being ignored.

It is hard to predict the future of newspapers. Many people think newspapers are in trouble. Since 2000, the number of people reading UK national newspapers has dropped by about one-third to one-half. In the USA, a study shows that only 26% of people get their news from newspapers, down from 45% in 2001. Some people believe that printed newspapers will disappear in the next 15 years. However, history shows that old forms of media often survive. 

For example, in 1835, a journalist in New York said that books and theater were finished and that newspapers would be the most important source of news. But theater survived, even with the rise of cinema and television. Radio is still popular today, and cinema has also done well against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are becoming popular again, with online sales increasing a lot since 2008.

Newspapers were once a new form of media, but it took a long time for them to become the main source of news. This change happened in the mid-19th century when new technologies like the steam press, railways, and telegraphs made it easier to share news quickly. People began to expect regular updates about the world around them, which was very different from the past when life was more predictable and slow.

Before the 19th century, journalism was not a full-time job for most people. There was no strong need for news every day or week. In some ways, having newspapers published regularly can be a problem. Now, with online news, people can read what they want when they want. They can also get updates on important stories very quickly. Mistakes can be fixed almost immediately, and there are no limits on how much information can be shared.

However, many news providers focus on being the first to report news rather than helping people understand it. In the past, news was often shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. Today, it seems we are going back to that way of sharing news. Newspapers have not always done a good job of explaining how the world works. They might disappear, or they might find a way to help us understand things better in this confusing world.

If humans were truly comfortable under the moon and stars, we would walk happily in the dark, just like many animals that are active at night. However, we are daytime creatures, with eyes that are made for sunlight. This fact is part of our nature, even if we don’t think about it. It helps explain what we have done to the night. We have changed the night by adding a lot of artificial light. This is similar to building a dam on a river. While there are benefits to this, it also creates problems, known as light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study.

Light pollution happens mostly because of poor lighting design. This means that artificial light shines in the wrong directions, lighting up the sky instead of focusing on the ground where it is needed. Bad lighting makes the night less dark, changing the light levels that many living things, including us, have adapted to. When human-made light spreads into nature, it affects many life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding.

For most of human history, the term ‘light pollution’ would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the largest city in the world. Almost a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns for light. Only a few homes had gas lights, and there were no public gas lights in the streets for another seven years. From a distance, you would have smelled London more than you would have seen its faint glow.

We have brightened the night as if it were empty, but that is not true. There are many nocturnal animals. Light is a strong force in nature, and it attracts many species. Scientists say that some birds, like songbirds and seabirds, can be ‘captured’ by bright lights, flying in circles until they fall. Birds that migrate at night often crash into tall buildings that are brightly lit, and young birds are especially affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at strange times because of artificial light.

At first, it was thought that light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. Most of us may not need a perfect view of the stars for our work, but we still need darkness. We cannot ignore darkness; it is just as important for our health as light is. Changing our natural sleep and wake cycles can lead to health problems. The regular pattern of waking and sleeping is connected to the natural light changes on Earth. These patterns are so important to us that changing them is like changing our balance.

In the end, humans are just as affected by light pollution as frogs living near a bright highway. By living in our own bright lights, we have lost touch with our natural and cultural history – the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe and the beauty of a dark night filled with stars.

The founder of a large international company recently said that his business will no longer keep track of how much paid holiday time employees take. This idea seems to come from a smaller internet company that has a similar policy. The founder mentioned that he got the idea from a happy email from his daughter, which many newspapers shared. However, some people think this way of announcing the change is just a way to make the policy seem friendlier, even if it might not be very generous.

Is this idea practical? The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational company has 50,000 employees and many different services, like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's work schedules. In a big company, it is hard to know if taking time off will hurt the business or their careers.

The founder said employees can take as much leave as they want, but only if they are sure their work is up to date and their absence will not harm the business. But is it really possible to be that sure? No matter how much work you finish before a holiday, there will always be more work waiting when you return. This means that employees might feel guilty about taking time off, which can lead to stress. If workers do not take enough leave, it could lower their productivity over time.

There can also be pressure from coworkers about who is taking time off and for how long. In many companies, there is a culture of working late, which could lead to a situation where employees feel they cannot take holidays, especially if they want to get promoted. If the legal rights to paid leave are taken away, workers might feel they cannot take the time off they need because they do not want to seem lazy.

This new policy could make employees feel stuck, as they might not take their entitled leave or only take the minimum amount of time off. Modern technology makes it hard to separate work time from free time because employees can receive work messages anytime and anywhere. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees wanted to know how to balance this new way of working with the old rules about time off.

However, having no set working hours can be a problem because it means that employees might feel they are always working. They may worry that their employer is watching them, which can lead to stress. Employment laws exist to protect workers, ensuring they have a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is important for their health. While the company hopes that unlimited leave will improve morale and productivity, I am not sure that allowing employees to take as much holiday as they want is really the best solution.

Peer review is the process where experts check a scientific research paper before it is published. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research. This process can delay the publication of a paper by up to a year. Some people think this delay is worth it to make sure the research is trustworthy, while others do not. 

I still believe in peer review, but I see changes happening. More researchers are using preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online before they are reviewed. Preprints help researchers share new findings quickly so others can read and discuss them. Publishing in journals has become more about gaining fame and advancing careers, which can change the motivations of authors and reviewers. 

Competition for space in top journals encourages scientists to do great work, but it can also lead to shortcuts. Sometimes, important data is left out to make a paper look better. Reviewers often focus on whether a paper is good enough for a specific journal rather than its overall quality. For top journals, what is popular or newsworthy can matter more than scientific quality.

Many people know about these problems, but few want to change the current system. However, some scientists believe that preprints could help. Even though preprints have been around for twenty years, not everyone uses them. Some scientists think that journals will not accept papers that have been shared as preprints. There is also a worry that publishing papers without peer review could lead to poor-quality research, but this has not happened yet.

Preprints may not be peer-reviewed, but authors know that their work will be open to feedback from a global community of reviewers. For example, Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. She said that when she critiqued another paper, the original authors could respond to her comments. This open discussion allows readers to judge the quality of the arguments. 

Preprint archives allow scientists to have informal discussions that used to happen only between individuals. They can also share negative results, which are often ignored by journals that focus only on new discoveries. Additionally, papers on preprint archives are read and cited more often, showing that sharing research this way is effective. By using the internet's openness and collaboration, preprints can help scientists focus on the research itself, not just where it is published.

When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say things like "a painting in words." Their answers usually do not satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group of students to choose an object and write two paragraphs about it. One paragraph was to describe the object like a scientist, and the other was to be from the object's point of view, titled "Poem." One student wrote: 

**Poem**  
I may look strange or scary, but I am a device that helps people breathe. I am only used in emergencies and for a short time. Most people will never need to use me. The object? An oxygen mask – a surprising choice that helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. This exercise led to laughter and good discussions.

When I was in school, poetry often confused me. I thought every poem was a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand feelings. After school, most people pay less attention to poetry. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it is not like regular writing. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or because you don’t understand it at first. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we hope to find in poems? Isn’t a poem a place for deep feelings, beautiful images, and clever thoughts? The answer seems to be yes. But if we want tears, we watch movies; for information, we read articles. Novels let us escape, paintings are nice to look at, and music is hard to beat with its mix of words and sounds. 

However, one thing a poem can do is show us uncertainty. Everyday life is full of uncertainty, unlike reading a sentence. But this still does not tell us what a poem really is. If you search online for "poem," it leads you to "poetry," which is described as a type of art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language. This is fine, but it does not explain the word's origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek word "poí?ma," which means "a thing made," and a poet is someone who makes things. 

So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – unpredictable and free – or to machines – carefully made and exact – depending on their views. But these comparisons can break down when we think about them closely. The best part of trying to define a poem through comparison is not the comparison itself but the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about both. It can help us see ordinary things in a new way.

Thinking of a poem as a mental object is not hard, especially when we consider how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and music has a strong effect, just like schoolyard rhymes such as "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a page of a newspaper or magazine, looking right at you: A poem can touch you like nothing else, even though it is just ink on paper, like the prose around it. 

What about the empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or an ad? A poem is written and rewritten just like an article or story, but it is not usually made to be sold. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry books, but few expect them to make money. A poem is not just a product for sale; it is something special. Because of its unique place in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. £70 was a lot of money back then, and it might have been better spent on something useful for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first trip. Over the years, every brooch and coin I found made me happy. I liked feeling connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion again.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I decided to go to a nearby spot where I knew there were old farming tools. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then, it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I had to check. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleaned it, I saw it was a beautiful, thick loop. I stopped and stared. I remembered seeing something like this before - the Great Torc, which is in the British Museum. It’s a famous necklace from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. The word "torc" means ‘twist’ and it is made of gold and silver. Each end has a gold ring like the one I found.

I took it to my car. On the way home, I kept looking at the torc on the passenger seat. I washed it in my kitchen sink, which was probably the first time it had been cleaned in a long time. “Marion!” I shouted, “I have something for you.” As I looked at my find, I heard my wife come into the room and stop. “What is it?” she asked after a moment. I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were afraid of damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. I was worried about it being stolen, so I eventually got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says that I must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before I gave it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned around, stopped talking, and looked at the torc. It was confirmed as real and later sold to my local council. Now, it is in the British Museum in London. I received £350,000, which was shared between the owner of the field and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find. It is something I have saved for the nation. People say to me, “Now that you found something so amazing, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing, especially if there is a chance to catch a bigger one tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things about traveling, but I don’t talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their carefully planned trips, where every moment is filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans often include time for naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in nice hotel beds?

Better sleep is one of the good things about traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours I spent sleeping—more than 12 hours most days. There were many noisy birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Far from home, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and enjoyably. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, I found it easier to sleep. 

I believe that sleep is not just a break from traveling; it is part of the travel experience. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. All these new experiences fill our minds, and when we sleep, we process them. This is why sleep feels different when we are traveling. 

People often worry about jet lag, but I think the problems I have after long trips are more about adjusting to new places and cultures than just time changes. For example, in Trinidad, people wake up very early to avoid the heat, then take a break around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and come back to life in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to get used to their different sleep patterns. When I finally adjust, I feel like I have truly arrived.

I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. I had a big lunch with new friends in an apartment with a view of the blue Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy, and one by one, my friends went to relax on hammocks and sofas. I understood why they had so many pillows on the floor. I took some pillows and joined them. I had heard about the Latin American custom of the siesta, but that day I really experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life.

Travel sleep has another great quality: I remember it. Being away from home, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep. If enjoying every moment of travel is what makes a good traveler today, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is an important part of the experience too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. “What do you think? Please be honest.” Mia picked up a medium-sized hat that was soft and had a pretty layer of fabric with a silk bow. “I still think this one looks best on you,” she said politely. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a funny face. “But it is so boring,” she said. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This beautiful little hat will make me stand out.” She patted the red and black mini top hat on her head. “Yes,” she said firmly, “this is the one I want.” 

Mia smiled and agreed that the woman would stand out at her daughter’s wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen’s thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since everyone was together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also looking forward to meeting Jen’s friend, Tattie. They didn’t know anything about Tattie, and Mia’s husband, Jeff, had quickly pointed this out when Jen called last week. “Tattie? What kind of name is that?” Jeff had said. “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia replied. “I think it’s nice.” “More like something very strange,” Jeff said. He didn’t like anything that seemed showy or pretentious. He also didn’t understand Mia’s way of being polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said that a trash can lid would look better on her. “The problem with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite.” 

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered her home, Medlar House. It took her only forty seconds to get home from work. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to turn the empty barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was not sure. “Do you really think people want to buy hats?” he asked. Mia knew from her friends that many women had trouble finding the perfect hat for special occasions, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became successful. Women came from far away to her shop in Little Pelham, where she made them feel welcome and allowed them to try on many hats until they found the right one. She encouraged her customers to bring their outfits so they could match everything perfectly. Recently, she also started selling handbags and costume jewelry.

It is a long way from London to Atlanta, and in his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye thinks about his amazing journey in sports. He feels confident but is also surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic final in discus to possibly starting a new career. Even though he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA.

In Atlanta, Lawrence is still learning about his new position in football. It is surprising that a 21-year-old from London, who is new to the sport, might be selected for one of the biggest teams in American football. But Lawrence is good at proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law, but he decided to focus on training for discus instead, after playing rugby before. In just 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world.

Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for discus, preparing for the world championships. He says, “Yes,” when asked if he is really considering a big NFL contract. He thought about American football before, but it seemed like a crazy idea at the time. After arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played football, he thought he could be good enough to attend the trials. “Pretty much,” he says. He applied online.

Was he nervous about being tested with experienced football players? “No,” he replies. “I don’t get nervous for many things.” He does not talk a lot, but he is sure of his abilities. His performance in tests showed that he was the most impressive player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he says, showing a bit of pride.

However, he is also cautious. He has no experience in football. How can he make it into an NFL team? “Coaches have told me I have the right skills. It’s all about how hard I work,” he answers. Will he be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness might come from his experience in the Olympic final, where he came last. He seems to have moved on from that disappointment and is proud that he qualified for the final with a great last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he says. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.”

After his Olympic experience, some people thought he might not recover. Lawrence does not want to talk about that. An NFL player’s minimum salary is over $400,000 a year, so there are clear financial reasons to switch sports. Lawrence has moved from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With all his physical talent, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would say that,” he replies. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”
