I had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty land below. The dark shades of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it was still summer in Siberia. I could see no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me. “Good morning, Robert,” he said with a slow, Russian accent. His name was Sergei, and he was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to sell safety clothing to the local mining companies. His English was not very good, and my Russian was not good either, but I used a dictionary to tell him that I was going to the city of Magadan in far-eastern Siberia with a one-way ticket. I planned to ride my bicycle back home to England. 

“But, Robert,” he said, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I told him I believed there was a road, but not many people used it. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will ride with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to explain with hand gestures that I had warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I was not sure if they would be good enough, especially my big postman’s over-trousers that I bought for £10.

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of tired students. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer was talking on and on. I was thinking about a problem. Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I wrote a note: “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” Al, my old school friend, was sitting in front of me. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, wrote something, and passed it back. I opened it and held my breath while I read, “OK.” 

Now, six years later, I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher. Although I was still learning how to manage my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and fulfilling. Plus, I had long holidays to go on adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. After our bike ride in Pakistan, Al caught the adventure bug and decided to cycle around the world instead of teaching. Since our first ride together, Al had taken on bigger challenges. This trip around the world by bike was his biggest challenge yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would be too hard for him. Even though it sounded difficult, I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure and facing new challenges every day. He was proving the doubters wrong who said he could not do it. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through tall pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to be part of this race. 

An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form confirmed that I was healthy, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay aware of my surroundings. I was told, “The horizon is your best friend,” and the pilot would tell me where to look. I also had to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything during the flight. When we started moving down the runway, I was nervous. My legs were up, my feet were away from the important pedals, and my hands stayed away from the switches. I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is a difficult part of high-speed acrobatic flying. To stay safe, you need to be calm and focused. You have to know when to tense up and when to relax. Panicking is not a good idea.

As we began to speed down the runway, I felt nervous. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and two seconds later, we turned sharply to the right. I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a moment, I felt like I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out and turned sharply left, diving down. My stomach felt strange as we flew down to 2,000 meters. 

Seconds later, we were just 10 meters off the ground, aiming for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, but I was surprised by a sharp right turn. We hadn’t even done any acrobatics yet. For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane, but my hand was shaking so much that the plane shook too. Then Dario said something, but I couldn’t hear him. Instead of answering, he did a barrel roll, turning the plane completely. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yes,” I replied. “Have you had enough?” he asked. “No,” I lied.

Then he did a loop, flying up and over, making a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. But I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, while we were upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw some fields. The flight was over in 10 minutes. It felt easy compared to what the pilots experience during the race. To show this, Dario took out some sandwiches and started eating as soon as we landed. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about the loop over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever seen amazing videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He says his favorite temperature is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned how to survive in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to make a wildlife documentary. "I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours, I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, and underwater work."

Now, he is a top cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series. "I started at a good time. When I began, not many people had been to Antarctica. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the cold man. It felt like there were many amazing scenes waiting to be filmed."

When he started 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very simple. "It is much easier to film today. Back then, if you filmed something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much material."

"My experience in cold conditions is very valuable. I feel comfortable there. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it feels normal to me. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes."

Allan says that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify the birds. Recently, he got permission to film in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would not be easy. It is a place for polar bears and is very dangerous. In April, it is usually -32°C, the wind is strong, and carrying cameras in deep snow is very hard. After walking for five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. 

On day 24, he felt like he was part of the bear world. "We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. After five hours of watching, I see something very quickly. The camera is ready, and I look through the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds, and then I see a black nose. The nose becomes a head, and in less than a minute, the bear is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She looks at me but does not care. Just as I think it can't get better, she slides down the slope. I think she is enjoying it," he says. Then, two cubs appear at the den entrance. "It is clearly their first view of the world. It is showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats."

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic. He wants to talk to the people who live there and see how it affects their lives. He believes he could make an amazing documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. This meant he had to swim in very cold water, deal with frostbite, and avoid polar bears. Eight months later, he also reached the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for a new adventure that he says is even more important. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined. This time, he and two friends will go on a three-month journey of 1,000 kilometers to the North Pole. They will measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and Pen knows the results will be very important for scientists. This work will show how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar region.

Pen was prepared for this job since he was a child. His father’s old nanny, who worked for the famous polar explorer Scott of the Antarctic, helped him become strong. She sent him out into the Scottish mountains during storms with very few clothes. His father also loved adventures in cold places, and Pen grew up to be very strong. 

Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and the outdoors. She helps him run his polar guide business. Mary says she worries more about him when he is at home because he often thinks about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a famous mountain event where horse riders compete with people running. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. They live in the countryside with their two children. Pen says it is harder to be away from them this time. When he last left, his son was only one year old, and he told him to take care of his mother and sister. His son took this very seriously and kept asking how they were, which became too much for him. Pen thinks it was not fair to put that pressure on his son.

For this trip, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while he is in the Arctic. He believes that calling them will remind them of how far away he is. In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He says that when he is on the ice, it is very hard to fix things or do anything complicated. He will be with Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a team of six people to help them by flying in supplies.

Pen feels that being part of a team can be stressful for him. He is also thinking about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained enough. He says that organizing things always seems more important than training, and he is worried about what he will have to do on the trip. Pen believes that this mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge, which is important for everyone. He admits that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time, the scientists will benefit from the information they gather. He wants to involve as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He believes this work is important, and they are the only ones who can do it. He feels that their unique skills are now very useful to society again.

Text: "I took a 'year off'. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. Even though I enjoyed these activities, I wanted to find something competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could try for an Olympic place if I felt inspired again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about Ben Fogle’s invitation: ‘Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?’ I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they were not very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog without pressure was interesting to me. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat, which made the race feel real. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would still take work to get the money. I also had to think about losing money by being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It feels good that people are interested in what I have done. But I find it hard to talk about my past without having a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just talk about what I did before. I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My training for the Olympics was hard, but it was also simple. I trained almost every day, but my training plan was clear, and I had doctors and dieticians to help me. I was worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV, but my worries went away as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing. It is also about mental strength. Ben had done tough challenges, but he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of understanding of his situation. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest with Ben about how much he needed to improve. I should have known what to expect when I agreed to race with him."

Text: 

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of cold, beautiful Arctic landscapes, maybe because I was tired of the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a job as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which is a pretty but basic location with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but I needed to know what I was getting into. "The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical," they said. I started packing right away.

November 6, London  
On my flight, I stared at a page with more than 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. I remembered that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. But now, I saw winter moving south, and the rivers were freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta  
The bus ride north was everything I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer cross the road. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" Anna asked. I followed the sound of barking, which got louder as I reached the dogsheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling the huskies out and getting them ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited, pulling against their ropes. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy to talk. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone told me to "Get in!" and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta  
I quickly learned how to be a husky guide, but first, I had to answer questions about what I could do. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know. Further questions showed that I was not very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. "You do have a driving license?" someone asked. I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw," I emailed my friends. "In the snow."

Text: 

On that day, when Paula Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters came to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was good enough to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe heal from an injury caused by an accident when she ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe said that she did not fully realize how important her achievement was at that moment. Looking back, she understands it was a big deal, but at the time, she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. She and her team had decided not to set any limits on their goals. Their motto was "no limits."

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could keep up her fast pace. He was worried she might have to drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry about this, but he understood that someone who didn’t know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers quickly, but she still managed to sprint the last distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, "I will come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that did not happen.

After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, helping her with her training as she ran 250-300 kilometers each week. He said, "I have worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could handle the pain like she could. She would make me work hard because I had to go deep into her muscles."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for a friendly greeting; Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. Hartmann said, "Paula would push you to your limits. That is what made her so good." He spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became upset.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, would do it. Maybe it's because people are racing against each other instead of racing against themselves." What does she mean? "It’s about always pushing yourself, even when you are winning. I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always about going as hard as I could." Radcliffe did not know it at the time, but that marathon was the best performance of her career. She would never run that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

Text: 

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ in Britain. I believed we had created a series that added something new to this movement, but I still worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and nervous. I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. 

In each project, I felt like I was on a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving travel and new experiences. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who makes golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent many years trying to reach their own ideas of perfection.

Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew I would disappoint some people by not including their favorites. I could imagine people asking, “Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that would please everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on their feelings, memories, and experiences.

Even though the book is called ‘Perfection’, I knew I wouldn’t say that the recipes were the best or final. I believed that by using my cooking skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, chefs, and their customers, I could find out what makes these dishes special. The dictionary says ‘perfection’ means being perfect, but it also means improving through practice. It’s about trying new ideas and changing them until you create something unique.

The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen before. I was excited to look into memories and feelings connected to food because I started my career in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me all over the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which made us stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I even hand-milked a cow and used dry ice to make ice cream, cooked chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burned my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.

Text: 

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, went off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the engine. He looked at it for a long time with his hands in his pockets and a serious look on his face. “Actually, I don’t know what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big and empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was better to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound sure. “Liar,” she said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind. They waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it got dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said. 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They talked about the music they were playing and their travels. 

“I think I’m going to Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. It sounded impressive, but she didn’t really want to go. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world. Because of this, she missed a lot of school and was not officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was lucky to be chosen from thousands of applicants. At the party, her dad gave her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to celebrate. Her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Lucy’s teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself. Her mother filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom said. Lucy thought her mom didn’t want to give her the chance to say no. Back then, Lucy believed it was wrong to complain, so she didn’t try to get out of it.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in and asked, “Tanglewood?” 

“Yeah.” 

“How old are you?” 

“Fifteen.” 

He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy didn’t mean to brag. It was hard to know when to share her achievements and when to be humble. 

“It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying…” 

“Excuse me,” Liesel/Louisa said, looking away as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed. “Have you ever been to Japan?” 

He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool. 

“Once. When I was about eight.” 

He started to reply when Lucy's grandfather came over. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone.” He took her arm and pulled her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” 

“They're not the competition.” 

“Everyone is the competition.” 

Her grandfather took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said. 

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, “You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” 

Lucy liked that. Being recognized felt good, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play difficult music. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

“It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,” said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to see what experts say about this topic – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a lot of real-life friends, a good sense of who they are, and are learning important skills for the digital world.

Simon Miles, an expert on online safety, says that social networking is now a big part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This is not necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it. 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the youth clubs that parents used to go to. It helps teenagers share jokes and gossip, and it helps them grow away from their parents and deal with teenage issues with their friends.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says that adolescence is a time when you ask, “Who am I?” Social networking can help with this. You can share your favorite music or sports, find out what you like, and see that other people think differently. Research shows that teenagers who use social media a lot are not as self-centered as those who don’t.

He also says that social media can help shy people. Talking online can be easier than talking face-to-face, and it can help you practice social skills in a less scary way. 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who like the same things. If you are one of the few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a group online with people who share your interest, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: young people can find new interests online, join groups with similar interests, and create their own content. She thinks social networking is becoming a way for teenagers to be creative. They are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites are also helping photographers connect, learn new skills, and share their work. 

This creativity can help them get jobs in the future. Every business uses social media to sell products and attract customers. If you create a product and have 1,000 friends on social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all your networks, you have a customer base.

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working. Matthews agrees that many sites offer chances to work with others to create and share content. Working together is an important skill in today’s world and helps with getting jobs in the digital age.

Text: 

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not think of a long trip across nine western states in the US and one Canadian province. But my parents wanted to have an adventure for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan a family trip that my twin brother and I were not excited about. “Not enough people do this anymore,” my parents said as we got ready for the trip, while my brother and I exchanged worried looks.

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, food, and clothes for any weather. I was excited but also worried about losing my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left in the car, we started our “Family Great American Road Trip.” As we left our big home for smaller places to stay for the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into.

We drove west through Oklahoma. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. We saw deserts turn into mountains. Each day felt similar, but we still had unique experiences. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were not for regular cars.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. We often had to deal with construction traffic. We laughed when we saw the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats. We experienced “bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross the road, which created some unforgettable moments.

As we drove, life at home felt far away. Even the old hotel we stayed in, which had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t stop our excitement. It was a 95-year-old building, but the views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we started our journey back home. My parents were right; you don’t need to go to a faraway place to find something special. 

It was nice to be home together again, and I was happy that I didn’t fight with my brother during our long trip. We took three thousand photos of our adventures, and I knew that I would remember the unexpected and fun moments the most.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and would live under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay at school, so she was happy to have the best room with a kitchen and study area. She also liked that she could use the Internet and phone for free. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, whether she liked it or not. 

So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had some vague memories of her grandmother and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very happy, but Daisy was excited to have Rose with her. Rose did not understand why her parents did not get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Because of this, Rose had spent her summers away from Daisy, even though she had happy memories of her from when she was ten years old. 

Dahlia told Rose that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose expected to get dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not like a typical old lady; she went to many social events. 

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But Rose wanted one thing: her independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She hoped her grandmother would trust her to do these things. 

Daisy understood. Rose’s mother gave her a new touch-screen mobile phone for emergencies only, and Rose was very happy about it. They all agreed that it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to make good choices, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them went too far, they would talk about it again. 

Rose was not a wild child. Her few friends were similar, so her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time she would change schools because she would be starting her final two years. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life.

Charlotte Grainger says that her primary school teacher first thought she might write a novel. “I believed that writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed like a challenge. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’ The novel I started then is about to be published.” 

Charlotte recently told her former teacher about her book, and the teacher was surprised. She thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40 years old. Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to do something she was good at.

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a great achievement: it has a strong story and is full of action. Nothing about it, except for the age of the main character, shows that it was written by a teenager.

A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn’t. She is confident and smart, but also calm, which keeps her from being too overconfident. Charlotte knows she is still young. When I ask her about the important moral questions in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughs and adds, “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about teenagers and how they are often shown in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She feels frustrated by these character types. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about teenagers who are not struggling in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers don’t know who they are because they lack experience. This can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but their books almost stopped her from writing. “My favorite fantasy writers explore deep ideas about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to write like them to create a good book and if I could do it.” However, she praises a book called *How Not to Write a Novel*. “It says that if the reader starts to guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone.”

Some people might think that Charlotte’s parents, who are both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father knew someone in publishing, which helped her book get read. She knows she is lucky because it is hard for anyone to get a first novel read, no matter their age. “Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. In the end, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

“Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,” said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. “Now, who wants to go first?” The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew up into the air, but something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. “Remember,” Gareth said kindly, “speed can be unpredictable.” 

I thought maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I was not like those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid of looking silly if I tried to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a training center for freestyle skiing in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students jumped and tried their new tricks, landing in foam cubes – not a real experience of skiing.

After practicing indoors, we went outside to try it for real. “Progression is inevitable!” the center’s slogan said. “Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,” Gareth explained. “But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.” The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is better. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important.

At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to slow down, and I often landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt tired. “You need to control the jump, not let it control you,” said Gareth. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises copied the moves we would do while ski-jumping, and others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body was doing while in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline.

We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of my achievement. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself go fast as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed correctly. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead of me, no longer attached to my feet.

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly to the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly goes up. There is a pause, then a quick drop that makes your stomach feel funny. You go fast forward, turn left sharply, and then go upside down. Everything around you is a blur, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be here, just like many others who pay to enter the theme park.

I find it interesting that amusement parks, with their exciting rides, are a big business. To create the thrills that people want, there are many teams of engineers and designers working behind the scenes. The job of a rollercoaster designer might sound like a dream for a child, but it is actually very challenging. They must create a ride that is both fun and safe, while also making it new and exciting for visitors.

Many people think that rollercoasters are getting more intense, but most of the designs we see today were created by a US designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. In the past, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers have to follow certain rules and use specific designs from ride manufacturers.

I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," said that the skill is in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts, an engineer, explained that it is important to quickly change between feelings of excitement and safety so that people enjoy the ride without feeling scared. 

To create a great ride, the teams must come up with a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, that fits with the ride's features, such as height and twists. However, Professor Walker said that in creative work, experience and testing are very important. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to love thrills when designing rollercoasters, so you know what riders want and can test the rides before they open.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers will use new technology like virtual reality. Walker said we should not expect too much from it. He explained that while virtual reality can make rides look exciting, the real experience of being on a rollercoaster is what people love the most, and that will continue to be important for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both things with her busy schedule. She says, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers can forget how hard it is to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, Miranda teaches and enjoys working with young dancers. She explains, “A new dancer is often open to trying new ideas. Working with students can be easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed, but they don’t always know their strengths and weaknesses. This means they can accept even tough criticism. Sometimes they challenge what I say, but I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. She says, “There may be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece of music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could be more experimental and change the music to improve the mood during tough rehearsals. But now, I mostly work on big productions where the music is already decided.”

Miranda believes in meeting new people and not sticking to one place. She says, “It’s important to make new contacts. But I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to change how I work each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing everywhere. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

The conversation shifts to a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, “There have been glamorous documentaries before that were not true. This one tries to show what life is really like in a dance company. There is a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I smiled because I understood her struggle. She knows she is not doing it right but can’t make her body do what is needed. It’s hard to watch, but it is real. People often underestimate the work and dedication needed in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She replies, “It’s when everything comes together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Perfection is hard to achieve, but aiming high is important for the audience. Sometimes I have worked on productions where the dance steps are good, but the costumes or props are distracting, and that is disappointing.”

Miranda has done many different types of work, so I ask her if she sees herself as a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She says, “People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There is a trend to focus on one area of expertise. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I will be known for one thing. For now, I just want to explore more.”

Text: "A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on TV. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation gave me the idea for my fun four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to carry it. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. I have walked on foot many times, but this was something very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I could stop at cafés along the way to relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. I often told people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England instead of talking about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website."

Text: "When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I usually travel with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I told him I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would join ten others to swim around the small islands. He still looked confused, but he smiled and showed me on board.

Before we started, our group had exchanged emails, but there was not much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would follow us, and they made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km. I felt nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, swimming at a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I also got faster and enjoyed them more. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come back again next year."

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many good things. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, I have a lot of free time, and my life is never boring. This makes it a great job for someone young like me! 

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to the passengers. Some of them let me help. 

Later, when I wanted to change from my banking job, I remembered this experience. At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people like me, and many of them were changing careers too. I practiced what to say before the interview. I talked about my skills and my work experience, not just that I loved to travel, like everyone else. Because of this, I got the job!

I think this job is great for many reasons, but the free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: 'no one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. 

When I am not working, I don’t have to take my work home. If I do have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I will probably never see them again!"

Text: "At the summer camp where I work, I enjoy seeing the children succeed at things they thought they could not do. Most of the children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but after some encouragement, they try, and they all reach the top in the end. This makes them feel great.

At the start of the week, some children miss home. It is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds who feel this way, not the younger ones. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and at the end of their week, they thank us because they had a great time.

Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call often to ask how their child is doing, which is not necessary. Their child is usually busy playing games or doing other activities, so we tell the parents to call back later.

We often see a certain type of child at camp, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important."

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, doing the show with an all-British cast was not easy. The UK has more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night. Everyone wants to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s great that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He told me that the young actors are very busy. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends,’ he said. 

What do his friends think of the show? ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them,’ he explained. When I told Jamie that I also play guitar, he found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! 

The young actors were already musicians, with some playing different instruments, but none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
